conversation.speaker: NURSE
conversation.text: Hello, I’m your nurse here in the Emergency Department. I see you just came from dialysis because they were worried about your blood pressure and a positive blood culture. How are you feeling right now—any dizziness, shortness of breath, chest pain, fever, or chills?

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: I feel a little tired, but that’s how I usually feel after dialysis. No chest pain or trouble breathing. I don’t feel feverish. I did have chills at dialysis the other day, but not right now. My blood pressure is always kind of low, they tell me.

conversation.speaker: NURSE
conversation.text: Thanks for telling me. The triage vitals show your blood pressure is on the low side, but that may be your baseline. The doctors are also concerned about that positive blood culture from dialysis, so they’ve started IV antibiotics here. I’m going to put you on the monitor and get some blood work while we wait for the ICU team to see you.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Hi, I’m one of the medicine residents. I’ve reviewed your chart: you have HIV, end-stage kidney disease on hemodialysis through a left subclavian catheter, atrial fibrillation, and trigeminal neuralgia. You were sent in because your blood cultures from dialysis grew bacteria and your blood pressure has been low. Can you walk me through what happened at dialysis over the last few days?

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: A couple of days ago during dialysis I got really cold and sweaty. They took some blood cultures and gave me an antibiotic through the machine. Then they called me back because the culture was positive, and today during dialysis my pressure dropped again, but they finished the treatment. They told me to come here.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: That matches what we have. The culture from dialysis showed gram-positive cocci in clusters, which is often a staph-type bacteria, and you received cefazolin and vancomycin there. Here in the ED you’ve gotten another broad-spectrum antibiotic. Your blood pressure is in the 80s to 90s systolic, which may be your baseline, but we’re being cautious because of the positive culture and your HIV. We’re going to admit you to the ICU for close monitoring and IV antibiotics.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: ICU? Am I that sick? I don’t feel that bad, just tired and a little lightheaded like after dialysis.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: We’re not seeing signs of severe infection right now—no fever, your exam is reassuring, and your chest X-ray doesn’t show pneumonia. But with your low blood pressure, positive blood culture, and HIV, we want to watch you closely. In the ICU we can monitor your blood pressure continuously, give fluids carefully since you’re on dialysis, and adjust your antibiotics. If everything stays stable, we can move you out quickly.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Okay, as long as someone explains what’s going on. My pressure is always low, they tell me at dialysis it’s in the 70s or 80s sometimes.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Your nephrologist confirmed that your usual systolic blood pressure is in the 80s to 90s, especially around dialysis, so that helps us interpret today’s numbers. We’ll still give you a small amount of IV fluid to see if that helps and keep an eye on your labs and lactate. If your blood pressure and symptoms stay at your baseline, that’s reassuring.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: I’m the ICU attending. I’ve reviewed your ED course and your history of HIV, ESRD on hemodialysis, atrial fibrillation, and trigeminal neuralgia. Your blood pressure is low but consistent with your reported baseline, and your lactate has improved after fluids. We’re going to continue IV vancomycin to treat the staph from your line and repeat blood cultures to make sure the infection is clearing.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Will you have to take out my dialysis catheter because of the infection?

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: Right now, the plan from the nephrology team is to treat through the infection with IV vancomycin given with dialysis for about two weeks, rather than removing the catheter immediately. We’ll watch your repeat blood cultures; if they stay negative and you remain stable, we can keep the line. If cultures stayed positive or you got sicker, we’d reconsider removing it.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Okay. I also get this sharp pain on the right side of my face and over my eye sometimes. It’s been there before from shingles, they said. It’s not too bad right now.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: That sounds like your trigeminal neuralgia from prior shingles. We’ll continue your pain medicines like oxycodone as needed and gabapentin, and we’ll keep you on valacyclovir as you were taking at home.

conversation.speaker: NURSE
conversation.text: We’re getting you settled in the ICU now. You’re on the heart monitor and blood pressure cuff. If you feel more lightheaded, short of breath, or have chest pain, please call right away. I’ll also be giving your regular HIV and dialysis-related medications as ordered.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Thank you. I usually feel dizzy and short of breath after dialysis until the next day, so I’ll let you know if it’s worse than usual.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: We’ve reviewed your morning labs. Your white blood cell count is low at 2.9, and your platelets are around 98, which is similar to your prior labs and likely related to your HIV. Your kidney numbers are high as expected with ESRD, and your potassium is mildly elevated at 5.4. Your lactate is normal at 1.7, which is reassuring against severe sepsis.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: So the infection isn’t making my blood bad right now?

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Your blood counts haven’t dropped suddenly, and you don’t have a high white count or fever. That, plus the normal lactate and clear chest X-ray, makes a severe bloodstream infection less likely at this moment. We still think the positive culture from your line is real, so we’re treating it with vancomycin and repeating blood cultures to be safe.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Alright. I just don’t want to end up on a breathing machine or something.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: Right now your oxygen level is good on room air, your lungs sound clear, and your chest X-ray doesn’t show any pneumonia. We have no indication that you’ll need a breathing machine, and we’ll keep monitoring you closely.

conversation.speaker: NURSE
conversation.text: I’m here to draw some more blood for your morning labs—checking your blood counts, kidney function, and electrolytes again. This helps the team see how you’re doing overnight.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Okay. I feel about the same, maybe a little tired. No new pain.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Your new labs are back. Your potassium is 5.4, which is a bit high, and your kidney numbers are up, which we expect between dialysis sessions. We’re going to give you a medication by mouth called Kayexalate to help bring the potassium down while we coordinate your next dialysis.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Is that why I feel a little funny in my chest sometimes?

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: High potassium can affect the heart, but your current level is only mildly elevated. We’re treating it early to prevent problems. We’re also watching your heart rhythm on the monitor because you have a history of atrial fibrillation.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: This morning your potassium spiked higher on a repeat lab—up to 7.9—so we treated that urgently and rechecked it. The follow-up labs show it has come back down to around 5.1 and then 4.1 later in the evening, which is much safer.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Wow, that sounds scary. I did feel my heart racing earlier.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: You did go into a fast heart rhythm—atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. We gave you IV diltiazem to slow your heart rate and then started you on diltiazem pills four times a day. Your heart rate has come down nicely.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Is that a new medicine I’ll have to keep taking at home?

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Yes. The diltiazem tablets are new for you, and you’ll continue them after discharge to help keep your heart rate controlled. We’ll include it in your discharge prescriptions and instructions.

conversation.speaker: CONSULT
conversation.text: I’m from the nephrology team. We’re following you for your end-stage renal disease and the line infection. You’ll continue your usual Monday-Wednesday-Friday dialysis schedule, and we’ll give vancomycin with dialysis for about 11 more days to complete a two-week course. We’ll also be careful not to remove too much fluid during dialysis, since aggressive fluid removal seems to drop your blood pressure and make you feel dizzy and short of breath.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Yes, when they take off a lot of fluid I feel awful afterward. So you’ll tell them to go easier next time?

conversation.speaker: CONSULT
conversation.text: Exactly. We’ll recommend smaller volume removal at your next dialysis session to help keep your blood pressure from dropping so much and reduce your symptoms.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Your repeat blood cultures drawn here have shown no growth so far, which is a good sign that the infection is under control. You’ve remained afebrile, your blood pressure is at your baseline, and you’re walking around without dizziness.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: That’s good to hear. When do you think I can go home?

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: Given your stable blood pressure, controlled heart rate, improving potassium, and negative follow-up blood cultures, we’re planning to discharge you later today with home health services. You’ll continue to receive IV vancomycin at dialysis, and we’ll send prescriptions for your HIV medications, dialysis-related meds, and the new diltiazem.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: I just moved here and don’t really have doctors yet. How will I get follow-up for my HIV and kidneys?

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: We’re arranging follow-up for you. You’ll need to see a new primary care doctor and an HIV specialist within the next week, and also follow up with your renal doctor. We’ll give you phone numbers to call to schedule those appointments, and we’re also giving you refills for your HIV medications, valacyclovir, dialysis-related meds like cinacalcet and sevelamer, and your prophylactic Bactrim.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: I haven’t been great about taking my HIV meds lately. I didn’t always have a place to get them. Is that going to hurt me?

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: Your HIV labs show a low CD4 count and a high viral load, which means your immune system is quite weak right now. That increases your risk of infections like this line infection. It’s very important to restart and stay on your HIV medications consistently. We’re concerned about your prognosis if the virus stays uncontrolled, so we’re emphasizing close follow-up with an HIV specialist.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: I understand. I’ll try to keep those appointments and take the meds like you say.

conversation.speaker: NURSE
conversation.text: I’m going over your discharge instructions. You’re going home with visiting nurse services. You’ll keep your regular dialysis schedule, and they’ll give you vancomycin through your line at dialysis for the next 11 days. Take diltiazem four times a day for your heart rate, and continue your HIV meds, valacyclovir, sevelamer, cinacalcet, aspirin, Bactrim on Monday-Wednesday-Friday, docusate, and folic acid as prescribed. Call your doctors or come back if you get fever, chills, worsening dizziness, chest pain, or trouble breathing.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Thank you for explaining everything. I’ll make sure to talk to my dialysis doctors about my low blood pressure too.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Hi Ms. ___. I’m one of the medicine residents. You came in from the dialysis unit after feeling faint, short of breath, and sweaty while you were on your way to see your kidney doctor. Can you tell me in your own words what happened today and over the last week or so?

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: I was walking to my appointment and in the lobby I suddenly felt really short of breath, lightheaded, and cold and sweaty. It’s been happening a lot. This past week I get short of breath just walking to the bathroom. I almost passed out in the shower last week. No chest pain, just feel like I might faint.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Thank you. In the emergency room your blood pressure was low but you were thinking clearly and your oxygen level was good on room air. They gave you an IV antibiotic dose and drew blood cultures, and your chest X-ray didn’t show any pneumonia or fluid in the lungs. Your EKG showed a normal rhythm. Does that match what you were told?

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Yeah, they said my pressure was low but that happens with dialysis. They did an X-ray and heart test and said they looked okay. I don’t remember all the details.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: You also mentioned some other symptoms—left-sided headaches you’ve been treating with Tylenol and Percocet, some nausea with a couple of episodes of vomiting a few nights ago, and right knee and thigh pain that’s been getting worse over weeks. Is that still going on now?

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Yes, the headache on the left is pretty constant, kind of achy. I’ve been taking Tylenol and Percocet around the clock. I had nausea and threw up twice a few nights ago but not today. My right leg still aches, especially the knee and thigh.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: I see. I also see in your chart that you have HIV and are on your medications, you’re on hemodialysis three times a week through the catheter in your left chest, and you’ve had trigeminal neuralgia or shingles on the right side of your face with chronic pain and eye involvement. You also have a history of atrial fibrillation and peripheral neuropathy. Is that all correct?

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Yes, I have HIV and I go to clinic for that. I’m on dialysis Monday, Wednesday, Friday. The right side of my face and eye have hurt since I had shingles there. And they told me I had an irregular heartbeat before. My feet and legs tingle a lot too.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: On exam right now your blood pressure is about 98 over 60, your heart rate is around 100, you’re breathing comfortably with good oxygen, and your lungs sound mostly clear with just faint crackles at the bases. Your heart sounds regular, your belly is soft and not tender, and your neurologic exam is normal. You do look a bit dry in the mouth. We’ll admit you to the medicine floor, keep you on the monitor, and check more labs to look for causes of the low blood pressure and shortness of breath.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Okay. I just don’t want to pass out again. Will you figure out why my pressure keeps dropping?

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: That’s our goal. We’re thinking about volume shifts from dialysis, possible adrenal gland problems, heart rhythm issues, or infection. We’ll keep you on telemetry, get an echocardiogram of your heart, and do blood tests including cortisol and repeat chemistries. We’ll also hold your diltiazem for now since it can lower blood pressure.

conversation.speaker: NURSE
conversation.text: Ms. ___, I’m your nurse on the floor. Your vitals right now are stable—temperature 97.7, blood pressure 98 over 60, heart rate 100, breathing 18, oxygen 98% on room air. I’m going to start your scheduled medications, including your HIV meds, dialysis-related meds, and eye ointment, and I’ll draw some morning labs a bit earlier because the team wants to check your calcium and kidney numbers.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Alright. I’m okay with the meds. My head still hurts on the left though. Can I get something for that?

conversation.speaker: NURSE
conversation.text: You have acetaminophen ordered as needed and also oxycodone if the pain is more severe. I’ll bring you some Tylenol first and see if that helps, and I’ll let the team know your headache is still pretty bad.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: Good morning, Ms. ___. I’m the attending physician. I’ve reviewed your labs from early this morning. Your calcium level is quite high at 12.7, your phosphate is 5.1, and your kidney numbers are elevated as expected with your end-stage renal disease. Your blood counts show a normal hemoglobin and platelets, with slightly large red blood cells. We think the high calcium may be contributing to your fatigue, nausea, and possibly your low blood pressure.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: High calcium? I didn’t know that could make me feel this tired and sick. Is that from my kidneys?

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: In people on dialysis, high calcium can be related to overactive parathyroid glands, adrenal issues, or, less commonly, cancers. Your parathyroid hormone level is elevated at 286, which fits with long-standing kidney disease, and your alkaline phosphatase is normal, which is somewhat reassuring. We’ll also check vitamin D and a parathyroid hormone–related protein, and we’ll use dialysis to help bring the calcium down. We’re continuing your cinacalcet to help control the parathyroid overactivity.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Okay. As long as it comes down. I’ve also been really nauseated sometimes. Is that from the calcium too?

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: It could be. Hypercalcemia often causes nausea and vomiting. We’re giving you anti-nausea medicine like ondansetron as needed, and we’ll also get liver tests and an ultrasound of your abdomen to make sure there’s no gallbladder or liver problem contributing. So far your liver enzymes and bilirubin are normal.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: That sounds good. My stomach feels okay right now, just a little queasy sometimes.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: We’re also concerned about your presyncope and low blood pressure. We’ll keep you on the heart monitor for now. Your echocardiogram is ordered to look at your heart function and valves. We’ll also do a cortisol stimulation test tomorrow to see if your adrenal glands are working properly.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Alright. I just want to know why I keep almost passing out. I’m scared it’ll happen at home again.

conversation.speaker: NURSE
conversation.text: Ms. ___, radiology is ready for your head CT because of your headaches. We’ll take you down now. It’s a quick scan and doesn’t use contrast.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Okay. My head has been really bothering me, so I hope it shows what’s going on.

conversation.speaker: CONSULT
conversation.text: Ms. ___, I’m from the radiology team. Your head CT shows no bleeding, no mass, and no stroke. There are some heavy calcifications along the membranes in your brain, which we often see in people with long-standing kidney disease, but nothing acute or dangerous.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: So no tumor or bleeding? That’s a relief. But why does my head still hurt?

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: We’re glad the CT is normal. Your headaches could be from migraine, tension, neuropathic pain, or even related to your HIV medications. We briefly tried carbamazepine this morning for possible trigeminal neuralgia, but we stopped it the same day. For now we’ll continue to treat your pain with oxycodone as needed and reassess as an outpatient for migraine-specific medications if needed.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Alright. The pain meds help some. I’ll talk to my regular doctor about other options later.

conversation.speaker: NURSE
conversation.text: Your evening labs just came back. Your calcium is still high at 11.7, and your ionized calcium is 1.45, which is elevated. Your pH is normal. The team plans to use your dialysis session tomorrow to help bring the calcium down further.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: So it’s still high. I hope dialysis helps. I usually feel wiped out after dialysis though.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: Good morning. Your labs this morning show your calcium has come down a bit to 12.0, creatinine is 10.0, BUN 62, and your electrolytes are otherwise stable. Your blood counts are acceptable, with hemoglobin 13.2 and platelets 179. We’ll proceed with dialysis today and avoid taking off fluid to prevent your blood pressure from dropping.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Thank you. I always feel like they take too much fluid off and that’s when I get dizzy. So no fluid off today?

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: Correct. Today’s dialysis will focus on clearing toxins and lowering your calcium, but we’ll avoid ultrafiltration. That should help keep your blood pressure more stable. We’ll also continue your cinacalcet and sevelamer, and we’ve started you on Nephrocaps for vitamins related to dialysis.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Okay. I’ll let you know if I feel lightheaded during dialysis.

conversation.speaker: CONSULT
conversation.text: Hi, I’m from nephrology. We’re managing your dialysis. Given your history of low blood pressure with treatments, we’ll run you today without removing fluid. We’ll also keep you on your usual Monday-Wednesday-Friday schedule and continue cinacalcet and sevelamer. Your phosphorus is mildly elevated but acceptable.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: That sounds good. I really don’t like feeling like I’m going to pass out during dialysis.

conversation.speaker: NURSE
conversation.text: We’re taking you down for your dialysis session now. Your blood pressure is in the 90s over 60s, heart rate in the 90s, and you’re afebrile. The dialysis orders specify no fluid removal today.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Okay, I’m ready. I’m a little nervous but I’m glad they’re not pulling fluid.

conversation.speaker: CONSULT
conversation.text: Dialysis went smoothly. We didn’t remove any fluid, and your blood pressure stayed in your usual low range without you feeling faint. This should also help bring your calcium down further.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: I feel tired but not as bad as usual. I didn’t get that same dizzy feeling this time.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: We also did your echocardiogram. It shows normal heart pumping function, normal chamber sizes, and no significant valve problems or pericardial effusion. There’s no structural heart reason for you to be passing out.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: So my heart is okay. That’s good to hear. Then it’s more from the dialysis and maybe the calcium?

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Exactly. We think your presyncope is most likely from fluid shifts with dialysis and possibly medication effects, rather than a heart structural problem. We’ve stopped your diltiazem, and tomorrow we’ll start a medication called midodrine to help support your blood pressure.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: I was on that diltiazem for my heart rhythm, right? It’s okay to stop it?

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: Yes. You have a history of atrial fibrillation, but during this stay you’ve been in normal sinus rhythm on the monitor. Given your low blood pressure, we think the risks of diltiazem outweigh the benefits right now, so we’re stopping it. If your rhythm issues recur, we’ll reassess with your outpatient doctors.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Alright. As long as you’re watching my heart while I’m here.

conversation.speaker: NURSE
conversation.text: Your afternoon labs after dialysis show your calcium has improved to 10.0, your creatinine is down to 4.7, BUN 22, and your potassium is 3.9. Your white count is a bit low at 3.6, and your red cells are still a little large, which is similar to your prior labs.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: So the calcium is better now. I do feel a bit less wiped out. My headache is still there but not as bad.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: That’s encouraging. We also drew cortisol levels at different times today and gave you a dose of cosyntropin to test your adrenal glands. Your cortisol levels, including after stimulation, show an appropriate rise, which means you do not have adrenal insufficiency.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: So my adrenal glands are okay too. That’s good. I’m glad you’re figuring this out.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: We also sent blood cultures from your arm and from your dialysis line. So far, the one that’s resulted shows no growth, and the others are still pending. You’ve remained afebrile and your white count is low-normal, so infection seems unlikely as the cause of your symptoms.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Okay. I was worried about infection because of my HIV and the dialysis line. I’m glad nothing is growing so far.

conversation.speaker: NURSE
conversation.text: Good morning. Your labs today show calcium 11.2, creatinine 7.0, BUN 45, potassium 5.0, and your blood counts are stable with hemoglobin 12.8 and platelets 166. Your white count is slightly low at 3.8, similar to before. The team is talking about sending you home later today if things stay stable.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Going home sounds nice. I do feel better than when I came in. Still a bit tired, but not as short of breath.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: We also completed your abdominal ultrasound. It shows no liver lesions, no bile duct blockage, and a normal gallbladder. There are many cysts in both kidneys, which we often see in people on long-term dialysis, and a small likely benign lesion in the spleen. No acute abdominal problem was found.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: So my liver and gallbladder are okay. That’s good. I was worried the nausea meant something was wrong there.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: We’re planning for discharge later today. To summarize: your low blood pressure and presyncope are most likely from dialysis-related fluid shifts and medications. Your heart structure is normal, your adrenal testing is normal, and your calcium, while still a bit high, has improved with dialysis. Your nausea has improved, and your headaches are better controlled. We’ll stop your diltiazem, start midodrine 5 mg once daily to help with low blood pressure, continue your HIV regimen and dialysis-related meds, and give you prochlorperazine and oxycodone as needed for nausea and pain. We’ll also arrange outpatient testing of your leg arteries (ABIs) for your right leg pain.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Thank you for explaining. I’ll stop the diltiazem and take the new blood pressure pill. I’ll also follow up about my leg and headaches. I’m glad my heart and scans were okay.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: Before you go, let’s review your discharge medications. Continue your HIV meds—atazanavir, lamivudine, ritonavir, and tenofovir weekly—as well as Bactrim on Monday, Wednesday, and Friday. Continue cinacalcet, sevelamer with meals and snacks, aspirin, valacyclovir, folic acid, Nephrocaps, docusate, and your eye ointment. New or changed: stop diltiazem and Percocet; start midodrine 5 mg daily, prochlorperazine 10 mg every 8 hours as needed for nausea, and oxycodone 5 mg every 6 hours as needed for pain. We’ll send you home today; you’re afebrile, your systolic blood pressure is in the 90–100 range, and you’re walking independently.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: That’s a lot, but I’ll follow the list you give me. I’m feeling better and ready to go home. Thank you all for taking care of me.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Hello, I’m one of the medicine residents. I understand you came in because of chest pain. Can you tell me in your own words what the pain felt like and when it started?

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: It woke me up two nights ago. It was right in the middle of my chest, kind of sharp and worse when I took a deep breath. It didn’t go down my arm or anything. It just stayed there for hours until they gave me a Percocet in the ER and then it went away.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Thank you. Any shortness of breath, sweating, nausea, or vomiting with the pain?

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: No, none of that. No trouble breathing, no sweating, no throwing up. It just hurt when I breathed in.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: In the emergency room your vital signs were stable and your oxygen level was normal. Your EKG looked okay, and your chest X‑ray didn’t show any pneumonia or fluid around the lungs. A CT scan of your chest also ruled out a blood clot in the lungs and any aortic problem. So far, this makes a heart attack or pulmonary embolism much less likely.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: So it’s not my heart? That’s what I was scared about.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Given your normal EKG, the CT scan, and your blood tests, we don’t see signs of a heart attack or a clot. Your troponin, a heart enzyme, is a bit elevated, but in people with kidney failure like you that can be chronically high, and your CK‑MB, another heart marker, stayed flat, which is reassuring.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: You also mentioned trouble swallowing and poor appetite since the day before you came in. Can you describe that? Does food get stuck, or is it painful when you swallow?

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: It hurts going down, like a burning and soreness behind my breastbone. I haven’t really wanted to eat since yesterday.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Given that, we’re thinking your pain may be coming from your esophagus or stomach rather than your heart. We’ll start a stomach acid medicine and a numbing/antacid mixture to see if that helps, and we’ll ask the GI team to evaluate you. We’ll also keep you on your usual dialysis schedule since you’re due for hemodialysis today.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Okay. As long as you can still get me to dialysis. I go Monday, Wednesday, Friday.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Yes, we’ll make sure you get dialysis here on your usual schedule. We’ll also continue your sevelamer and cinacalcet for your kidney disease and parathyroid issues.

conversation.speaker: NURSE
conversation.text: I’m your nurse tonight. Your blood pressure, heart rate, and oxygen look good. If you have any more chest discomfort or trouble swallowing, please call me right away. I’ll bring your pain medicine and stomach cocktail shortly.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Thank you. My chest doesn’t hurt right now, but my muscles and joints ache like usual.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: Good morning. I’m the attending on the medicine service. I see your chest pain has resolved. On exam your heart sounds are regular, lungs are clear, and there’s no tenderness over your chest wall. That fits with what we’re seeing on your tests.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Yeah, the chest pain is gone. It’s mostly the swallowing and my usual body pains now.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: Your blood work this morning shows your hemoglobin is a bit low at around 9, which is similar to your usual anemia from kidney disease. Your white count is slightly low, and your electrolytes and calcium are okay for you. We’ll continue your folic acid and epoetin with dialysis.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: Because of your HIV and the swallowing pain, we’re concerned about possible esophagitis or gastritis. We’ve started omeprazole and will have GI do an upper endoscopy in the next couple of days. For now, we’ll keep you on a soft diet as tolerated.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Okay. I’m not on my HIV meds right now. Are you going to restart those?

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: You’ve been off HAART because of past adherence issues. Our infectious disease colleagues know you and will see you again. During this stay we’re restarting your prophylaxis with Bactrim and azithromycin to prevent infections like PCP and MAC. Restarting full HIV therapy will be coordinated with your outpatient ID doctor, especially since omeprazole can interact with some HIV meds.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: I understand. I’ll talk to them, but I want to make sure I can actually take everything this time.

conversation.speaker: NURSE
conversation.text: You’ve just spiked a fever to a little over 102. We’ve drawn blood cultures and started IV vancomycin and cefepime as ordered. Let me know if you feel worse—shortness of breath, chest pain, or chills.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: I feel really cold and achy. Is this from my line?

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: This morning your fever from last night is documented, and your blood cultures from that time have now grown coagulase‑negative staph, a skin bacteria that often infects dialysis catheters. We think your hemodialysis line is the likely source of your bloodstream infection.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: If it’s the line, does that mean you have to take it out? I’ve already had so many fistulas fail.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: We’re very aware that your access is limited. But because you’re still having fevers despite vancomycin, and the cultures show bacteria that like to stick to plastic, the safest way to clear the infection is to remove this catheter. We’ll coordinate with nephrology and interventional radiology to remove it and then place a new temporary dialysis line, likely in your groin, after a short ‘line holiday.’

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: I’m scared about losing this line, but I don’t want the infection to get worse either.

conversation.speaker: CONSULT
conversation.text: I’m from the infectious disease team. Your blood cultures show coagulase‑negative staph that’s sensitive to vancomycin. We agree with continuing IV vancomycin and stopping cefepime once we’re sure there’s no gram‑negative infection. Because of persistent fevers, we support removing the current dialysis catheter and then treating with several weeks of vancomycin, dosed with dialysis.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Will I have to keep getting vancomycin after I leave the hospital?

conversation.speaker: CONSULT
conversation.text: Yes. The plan is for you to receive vancomycin with your dialysis sessions for several weeks after discharge. The nephrology team will follow levels and adjust the dose. You may also receive antibiotic ‘locks’ in the new catheter to prevent re‑infection.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: Your upper GI barium study yesterday showed no ulcers or strictures in the esophagus, and the barium passed freely into the stomach. That’s reassuring. We’re still planning an endoscopy to look directly at the stomach and duodenum.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: The swallowing is a little better with that purple pill you started. I still get some burning, though.

conversation.speaker: CONSULT
conversation.text: We did your endoscopy this morning. We saw redness and small petechiae in the stomach lining consistent with gastritis, and redness in the duodenal bulb consistent with duodenitis. There were no ulcers or obvious infections like Candida or CMV. We took biopsies, and we recommend continuing omeprazole 20 mg twice daily.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: So that explains the burning? Do I need to change what I eat?

conversation.speaker: CONSULT
conversation.text: The gastritis and duodenitis likely explain much of your burning and discomfort, though they don’t fully explain the high fevers you had. We suggest avoiding very spicy or acidic foods and continuing the acid‑suppressing medicine. Your primary team will also watch for any medication interactions when HIV therapy is restarted, since omeprazole can conflict with some regimens.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: We attempted to place a new dialysis catheter in your neck yesterday, but the venogram showed that both your central left and right subclavian veins are occluded. Because of that, interventional radiology plans to place a tunneled femoral dialysis catheter in your right groin today.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: In my groin? Will I still be able to walk around? And is that safe with the infection?

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Yes, you’ll still be able to walk, but we’ll ask you to avoid heavy lifting or strenuous activity with that leg. The femoral catheter is being placed after a short line holiday and while you’re on appropriate antibiotics, so it’s an accepted approach when upper‑body veins are blocked. We’ll monitor closely for any new signs of infection.

conversation.speaker: CONSULT
conversation.text: Your new tunneled femoral dialysis catheter was placed successfully this morning. The tip sits in the right atrium and is ready for use. We’ll coordinate with dialysis to resume your treatments through this line.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: It’s sore down there, but I’m glad I can get dialysis again.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: Your fevers have come down, and the follow‑up blood cultures after the line removal have all shown no growth. That suggests the bacteremia is clearing with the vancomycin and the new catheter.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: That’s good to hear. I still feel tired and achy, but not as bad as before.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: We repeated your chest X‑ray yesterday because you had another fever. It showed a new small left lower lobe pneumonia. We started cefepime again, but your cultures have stayed negative and your fever resolved. A follow‑up chest X‑ray now shows that the opacity has largely cleared, so we’re stopping cefepime.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: I didn’t even feel much in my lungs, just the fevers. I’m glad it’s going away.

conversation.speaker: CONSULT
conversation.text: From an HIV standpoint, your CD4 count is low and you’ve had PCP in the past. We strongly recommend staying on Bactrim three times a week and azithromycin twice weekly. We’ll defer restarting full HAART to your outpatient ID doctor, but it’s important to plan for that soon.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: I’ll take the Bactrim and azithromycin. I know I need to get back on the HIV meds, but I want to talk it through with my doctor at clinic.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Your hemoglobin has been running in the 8–9 range, which is your baseline anemia from kidney disease. Your white count is low but stable, and your platelets are normal. We’re continuing folic acid and epoetin, and there’s no sign of active bleeding.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: I do feel tired, but that’s how I usually feel with my kidneys.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: We also checked your left arm with an ultrasound because of some swelling. The study showed no evidence of a blood clot in the veins there, which is reassuring.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Good. I was worried about clots with all these lines.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: At this point your chest pain has resolved, your swallowing is improved on omeprazole, your bacteremia has cleared with vancomycin and line removal, and your pneumonia is resolving. You’re walking independently, and your vital signs are stable. We’re planning to discharge you home with visiting nurse services.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: I’m ready to go home. What medicines do I need to keep taking, and what should I watch out for with this groin line?

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: At discharge you’ll continue: sevelamer with meals, cinacalcet daily, omeprazole 20 mg twice daily, Bactrim three times a week, azithromycin twice weekly, Nephrocaps, folic acid, aspirin 81 mg daily, and Percocet as needed for pain. You’ll also receive IV vancomycin at dialysis for about 10 more days, dosed per dialysis protocol. For the groin catheter, avoid strenuous activity, keep the dressing clean and dry, and call if you notice redness, swelling, drainage, or fevers.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Okay, I’ll go over the list with my dialysis nurses and my HIV doctor. Thank you all for taking care of me.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Hi, I’m one of the emergency room doctors. I understand you were getting an extra dialysis session today and started feeling very short of breath and light‑headed, and your blood pressure was low. Can you tell me in your own words what’s been going on over the last few days?

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: For a few days I’ve been getting more short of breath when I walk around. I thought it was fluid, so they brought me in for extra dialysis today. After they took fluid off I felt really weak, dizzy, like I was going to pass out. They told me my pressure was in the 80s. I never had chest pain, no cough or fevers.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Thank you. I see in your chart that you have HIV and are currently off your HIV medications, and you’re on hemodialysis for kidney failure. You also have a history of low blood pressure after dialysis in the past. Is that right?

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Yes. I’ve had HIV for years. I haven’t been taking the HIV meds lately. I go to dialysis three times a week. Sometimes after dialysis my pressure drops and I feel like I might pass out. They stopped one of my blood pressure pills before because of that.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: You also have a right groin dialysis catheter in place, and I see notes that you’ve had problems with clots in your central veins before, which made placing lines in your neck difficult. We may need to use that groin line for access today. We’re going to get blood tests, an EKG, and a chest X‑ray, and we’ll give you some fluids carefully. If your blood pressure stays low, we may need to use medications to support it for a short time.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Okay. I’m scared about my blood pressure being so low, but do what you need to. Just be careful with the fluids because of my kidneys.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: We’ve checked your vital signs: your temperature is normal, your heart rate is in the 60s, your blood pressure is around 82 over 40, and your oxygen level is 100% on room air. Your lungs sound clear and your heart sounds regular. We’re going to start a small fluid bolus and a brief medication to support your blood pressure while we sort out the cause. We’ll also draw labs including kidney function, blood counts, and heart enzymes.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Alright. I don’t feel short of breath just lying here, just kind of wiped out and light‑headed.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Your initial labs show your kidney numbers are high, as expected with your end‑stage renal disease: your creatinine is 8.6 and your BUN is 69. Your blood counts show a mild anemia and low platelets, and your white count is a bit low. Your troponin, a heart enzyme, is 0.42, which is higher than your usual baseline of around 0.15–0.25, but your CK and CK‑MB are not elevated. Your EKG doesn’t show any signs of a heart attack. We’ve asked cardiology to weigh in.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Does that mean I’m having a heart attack?

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Right now, we don’t think so. The cardiology team feels that with no chest pain, a normal EKG, and flat CK and CK‑MB, the troponin bump is likely a mild leak from the low blood pressure and your kidney disease, not a classic heart attack. We’ll keep checking your heart enzymes, but they’re not recommending any invasive heart procedures at this time.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: We’ve done a chest X‑ray, which shows clear lungs and no signs of pneumonia or fluid overload. We’re also sending you for a CT angiogram of your chest to rule out a blood clot in your lungs, given your shortness of breath and low blood pressure.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Okay. I’m not really short of breath now, but I was when I was walking earlier. I just want to make sure it’s not a clot.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Your CT angiogram is back. There’s no evidence of a pulmonary embolism. It does show narrowing of some of the large veins in your chest—the left subclavian and both brachiocephalic veins—with a lot of collateral veins, but the main vein to the heart, the SVC, is still open. That fits with your history of difficult central line placement. There’s no pneumonia or other lung problem on the scan.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: So no clot in my lungs and no pneumonia. That’s good. Why did I get so short of breath then?

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: We think your shortness of breath was from being fluid overloaded before the extra dialysis, and then the low blood pressure happened after too much fluid was taken off. Your breathing improved after dialysis, but your pressure dropped. Right now your blood pressure is stabilizing with a small fluid bolus and brief support from medications, and your oxygen level has stayed normal.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: I’m the ICU attending. We’re going to admit you to the MICU for close monitoring of your blood pressure. You were briefly on a medication to support your pressure, but we’ve already been able to turn that off as your pressure improved with fluids. We’ll also start broad‑spectrum antibiotics tonight—vancomycin and piperacillin‑tazobactam—just in case there’s an infection causing low blood pressure, while we wait for cultures. If everything stays negative and you remain stable, we’ll stop them.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Alright. I don’t feel sick like with an infection, but I understand you want to be safe.

conversation.speaker: NURSE
conversation.text: We’ve moved you up to the MICU. Your blood pressure is now in the low 100s systolic, which you say is close to your usual. You’re on the monitor, and your oxygen is still 100% on room air. If you feel dizzy or more short of breath, please call us right away.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: I feel better than before, not really dizzy now. Just my usual headache.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: This morning your blood pressure has remained stable without any medications to support it. Your lactate, which was elevated when you were hypotensive, has come down. You’re not short of breath at rest, and your exam is unchanged. We’ll plan to transfer you out of the MICU to the regular medicine floor later today if things stay this way.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: That sounds good. I’d rather be on a regular floor if I don’t need the ICU.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: We’ve repeated your labs. Your hemoglobin has dropped from 11.8 to 9.8, and your platelets are around 107. Your white count is still low at about 3.2. Your kidney numbers are a bit higher this morning—creatinine 9.9 and BUN 94—and your potassium is elevated at 7.1, with an anion gap of 25 and bicarbonate of 21. We’re arranging hemodialysis today to address the high potassium and volume status.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: I know my blood counts are usually low, but the platelets being low is new? Is that from my HIV?

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: You’re right—your anemia and low white count are chronic, but the thrombocytopenia is newer. We’re not sure of the exact cause yet. It could be related to bone marrow suppression from active HIV. We’re going to trend your platelets and also look for other causes, including checking for signs of lymphoma or other malignancy, since your LDH is elevated and you have some other lab abnormalities.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Lymphoma? That sounds scary. What are you going to do to check for that?

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: We’re starting with imaging. We’ve ordered an abdominal ultrasound to look at your spleen and lymph nodes in your abdomen, since lymphoma can cause an enlarged spleen or enlarged lymph nodes. We’re also doing more detailed blood tests, including protein electrophoresis and immunoglobulin levels, to see if there’s a pattern suggesting a blood cancer versus a more benign immune activation.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Okay. I’d like to know what’s going on, but I’m nervous about more bad news.

conversation.speaker: NURSE
conversation.text: We’re getting you ready to go down for your abdominal ultrasound. After that, you’re scheduled for dialysis. Your blood pressure is stable and you’re on room air.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Alright. Will dialysis be the same as usual through my groin catheter?

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Yes, dialysis will be through your right groin catheter as usual. We’ll be careful about how much fluid we remove this time to avoid dropping your blood pressure again. Nephrology has ordered heparin, doxercalciferol, and your usual cinacalcet and sevelamer to continue your ESRD regimen.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Please tell them not to take too much fluid. I don’t want to feel like I did when I came in.

conversation.speaker: NURSE
conversation.text: You’re back from ultrasound. The radiologist’s preliminary read is that your spleen is borderline enlarged, but they don’t see any big lymph nodes in your abdomen. They also see a lot of cysts in your kidneys, which you’ve had before. We’ll let the team discuss the full report with you.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: So they didn’t see any big tumors or anything?

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: I’ve reviewed your abdominal ultrasound. Your spleen is borderline enlarged at 12.9 cm, slightly bigger than on a prior study, and there are a couple of small bright spots in the spleen that look like benign hemangiomas. There’s no sonographic evidence of enlarged retroperitoneal lymph nodes. Your kidneys have many cysts, which is unchanged. So, at this point, we don’t see imaging evidence of lymphoma in your abdomen.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: That’s a relief. What about those blood tests you mentioned?

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: The blood tests show your LDH is elevated, and your beta‑2 microglobulin, IgG, and IgM levels are all high. The protein electrophoresis pattern is consistent with polyclonal hypergammaglobulinemia, which means your immune system is broadly activated rather than a single clone of cells overgrowing. That’s more consistent with chronic HIV‑related immune activation than with a classic lymphoma pattern, but we’ll need to follow these over time as an outpatient.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: So it’s not definitely cancer, but you want my doctors to keep an eye on it later?

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Exactly. Right now, we don’t have imaging or lab evidence that clearly points to lymphoma. We do see this polyclonal hypergammaglobulinemia and elevated beta‑2 microglobulin, which we’ll flag for your outpatient team to monitor. If your platelets or other counts worsen, they may consider more invasive testing like a bone marrow biopsy, but that’s not planned during this short stay.

conversation.speaker: NURSE
conversation.text: Dialysis is starting now. The nephrology team has set a conservative fluid removal goal to avoid dropping your blood pressure. We’ll monitor your vitals closely during the session.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Thank you. I’m feeling okay right now, just tired.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: You’ve done well overnight. Your blood pressure has stayed in your usual range without any support, and you haven’t had any more shortness of breath. Your oxygen levels have been normal, and your chest imaging and CT ruled out pneumonia and pulmonary embolism. Given your stability, we’re transferring you from the MICU to the medicine floor.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: I’m glad I’m breathing fine now. I don’t feel short of breath anymore, just my usual fatigue.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: On the floor, we’ll continue your regular Monday‑Wednesday‑Friday dialysis schedule. We’re also continuing your cinacalcet and sevelamer, and we’ve increased your sevelamer dose to better control your phosphorus. You’ll stay on Bactrim prophylaxis, and we’ve restarted azithromycin prophylaxis for MAC, since your CD4 count has been low. We’re not restarting full HAART during this admission because of prior non‑adherence; that will be coordinated with your outpatient HIV doctor.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: I’ve been taking the Bactrim at home. I know I haven’t been good about the HIV meds. I’ll talk to my ID doctor about restarting them.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: This morning’s labs show your hemoglobin is 10.6, hematocrit 33.9, platelets 108, and white count 2.2. Your creatinine is 6.2 and BUN 51 after dialysis, potassium is 5.1, and your calcium is a bit low at 7.9. These are all acceptable for you, and there’s no sign of active bleeding. Your troponin has not risen further, and your EKG remains without ischemic changes.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: So my blood counts are still low but stable, and my kidneys are about the same as usual after dialysis?

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Yes, that’s right. Your anemia and leukopenia are chronic and stable, and the platelets are still low but not dropping further. Your kidney numbers are consistent with your ESRD and improve after dialysis. We’ll continue to monitor, but there’s no indication for transfusion.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: From a breathing and blood pressure standpoint, you’re doing well. Your shortness of breath has resolved, and your blood pressure has been stable on the floor. We think the hypotension was due to too much fluid being removed during that extra dialysis session. Your infectious workup, including blood cultures, has been negative, and you’ve been afebrile, so we’ve not continued broad‑spectrum antibiotics beyond the initial doses in the ED.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: I feel back to my usual now. No shortness of breath, and I can walk to the bathroom with my cane.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: We also did an echocardiogram, which showed an atrial septal defect and mild mitral regurgitation, but your heart’s pumping function is normal and there’s no sign of significant pulmonary hypertension. These findings don’t change your management right now but will be important for your outpatient cardiology follow‑up.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: I didn’t know I had a hole in my heart. As long as it’s not causing problems now, I’ll follow up as you say.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: We’re planning to discharge you home today. You’ll continue your regular dialysis schedule. We’re increasing your sevelamer dose to 4000 mg three times a day with meals to better control your phosphorus. Your discharge medications will include cinacalcet, sevelamer, Bactrim with each dialysis, weekly azithromycin, docusate, aspirin 81 mg, folic acid, hydroxyzine as needed for itching, and oxycodone‑acetaminophen as needed for pain.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Okay. Can you go over the changes again so I don’t miss anything when I get home?

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Of course. The main change is that your sevelamer dose is higher—4000 mg three times daily with meals. We’ve also formalized your prophylaxis: Bactrim with each hemodialysis session and azithromycin once weekly. Everything else is essentially a continuation of what you were already taking. We’ll send a detailed list with you, and your dialysis unit will also have the updated orders.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: Before you go, to summarize: you came in with shortness of breath and then low blood pressure after an extra dialysis session. We ruled out pulmonary embolism and heart attack, and your breathing and blood pressure normalized with a small fluid bolus and careful dialysis. We found some lab abnormalities—elevated LDH, beta‑2 microglobulin, and immunoglobulins, plus new thrombocytopenia—but imaging and blood studies suggest polyclonal hypergammaglobulinemia rather than a clear lymphoma. These will need outpatient follow‑up. You’re stable, alert, and able to walk with assistance, so we’re comfortable sending you home today.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Thank you for explaining everything and for taking care of me. I’ll follow up with my kidney and HIV doctors like you said.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Hi, I’m one of the emergency room doctors. I understand you were sent here from dialysis because of pain and drainage around your right groin dialysis catheter. Can you tell me in your own words what’s been going on with that leg and line over the last few days?

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Yeah, the spot where my dialysis line goes into my right thigh started hurting a little a few days ago. Then it got more swollen and tender, and this morning I saw pus around it. They did my whole dialysis run anyway and gave me some vancomycin there, then sent me here when they saw how bad it looked.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Thank you. We’re also seeing that your blood pressure is on the low side right now, around the 80s over 40s to 80s over 50s, which can happen after dialysis and with infection. We’ll give you IV fluids and start antibiotics. Have you had any fevers, chills, chest pain, or shortness of breath today?

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: I had chills this morning before dialysis, but no real fever that I know of. No chest pain or trouble breathing. Mostly it’s the pain in my leg and feeling kind of weak and lightheaded.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Okay. We’re going to draw blood, including cultures to look for infection in your bloodstream, and start you on IV cefepime and more vancomycin to cover line infections. We’ll also get a chest X‑ray and an EKG because of your low blood pressure. You mentioned you’re on hemodialysis for HIV‑related kidney disease and that you’re not taking HIV medications right now, but you are taking Bactrim and azithromycin for infection prophylaxis, correct?

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Yes, I’m on dialysis because of my HIV kidneys. I haven’t been able to stay on the HIV meds, they make me sick. But I do take the Bactrim three times a week and the azithromycin once a week like my doctor told me.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Your initial labs show your kidney numbers are high as expected with dialysis, but your potassium is okay at 4.4, and your lactate is mildly elevated at 2.2, which can go along with low blood pressure and infection. Your liver tests are normal. We’re going to admit you to the ICU because of the low blood pressure and suspected infected dialysis catheter. Interventional radiology has already removed the right femoral catheter at the dialysis unit, so we’ll need to arrange new access soon.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: ICU? Am I that sick? I feel a little better after the fluids, just tired. I’m worried about how I’m going to get my dialysis now that they pulled that line.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: We’re bringing you to the ICU mainly to watch your blood pressure closely and manage the infection. Right now your pressure has come up into the 90s over 60s after about 3 liters of IV fluid, and you’re not needing any medications to raise it. We’ll coordinate with nephrology and interventional radiology to get a new dialysis catheter placed once the infection is under control.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Okay. My throat has also been hurting for a few weeks, and my neck too. It gets better when I take Percocet. Could that be from thrush or something?

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Given your HIV and the throat pain, we are concerned about possible oral candidiasis. We’ll have ENT examine your mouth and throat, and we’re going to start a nystatin mouthwash to treat possible thrush. We’ll also continue your pain medicines, including oxycodone and acetaminophen, and your hydroxyzine for itching.

conversation.speaker: NURSE
conversation.text: I’m going to give you your evening medications now: your cinacalcet and folic acid for your kidneys and anemia, your sevelamer with dinner to bind phosphorus, and your usual HIV prophylaxis meds on their schedule. If your throat hurts, I’ll bring the nystatin rinse as ordered.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Thanks. My leg where the line was pulled is really sore. It feels swollen and warm there.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: On exam, there’s about a 10 by 10 centimeter area on your right upper thigh that’s tender, a bit warm, and fluctuant where the old catheter tunneled. We’re going to get an ultrasound of that area to make sure there’s no abscess that needs to be drained.

conversation.speaker: CONSULT
conversation.text: I’m from the ultrasound team. We just scanned your right upper thigh where the old dialysis catheter was. There’s a lot of soft tissue swelling and a small amount of fluid under the skin, but no organized pocket of pus that we can drain. The main femoral artery and vein are open and flowing normally.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: So you don’t have to cut it open? I’m glad. It still hurts a lot though.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Your blood work this morning shows your white count is low at about 3.1, your hemoglobin is 11.3, and your platelets are a bit low at 108. Your kidney numbers are still high, with creatinine 6.6 and BUN 42, which is expected since you haven’t had dialysis since the line was pulled. Your troponin is mildly elevated at 0.36, but your CK and CK‑MB are normal and your EKG doesn’t show a heart attack. We think this is a stress‑related troponin rise in the setting of low blood pressure and kidney disease, not a heart attack.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: I’m not having any chest pain, so I’m relieved it’s not a heart attack. I do feel tired and kind of wiped out.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: Your chest X‑ray from yesterday looked good—your lungs are clear and your heart size is normal, with no signs of pneumonia or fluid overload. That’s reassuring given your low blood pressure and HIV.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: That’s good to hear. Breathing feels okay. It’s mostly the leg and just feeling down. I’ve been really depressed lately.

conversation.speaker: CONSULT
conversation.text: I’m from psychiatry. I understand you’ve been struggling with depression and also with sticking to your HIV medications. From what you’ve told us, you’re feeling very low but you don’t have active thoughts of harming yourself. Given your side effects with amitriptyline in the past, we’re not going to start a new antidepressant in the hospital, but as an outpatient your team may consider a low‑dose mirtazapine and close social work follow‑up.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Yeah, I don’t want to hurt myself, I’m just tired of being sick all the time. I’d be willing to talk to someone as an outpatient, but I’m nervous about more meds.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: We’ll make sure social work and your primary HIV doctor are involved after discharge. For now, we’ll keep your prophylaxis with Bactrim and azithromycin, but we won’t restart full HAART while you’re here, in line with your outpatient plan.

conversation.speaker: CONSULT
conversation.text: I’m from ENT. We examined your throat and larynx. There’s no mass, but there are findings consistent with oral candidiasis. Continuing the nystatin swish and swallow for a 6‑day course is appropriate, and you’ve already reported some improvement in your throat pain.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: The mouthwash tastes awful, but my throat does feel a bit better than when I came in.

conversation.speaker: CONSULT
conversation.text: I’m the interventional radiology fellow. We tried to place a new tunneled hemodialysis catheter through your left common femoral vein today. We were able to get into the vein and start tunneling, but we couldn’t advance the catheter fully and you asked us to stop, so we removed it. There were no immediate complications, but you still don’t have a working dialysis catheter yet.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: I remember, it was really uncomfortable and I got scared. I know I need dialysis though. Are you going to have to try again?

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: Yes, we do need to get you a new catheter so you can resume dialysis. Tomorrow, interventional radiology will try again, this time with general anesthesia so you’ll be asleep and more comfortable. Because of your history of difficult access and prior venous stenosis, it can be technically challenging, but they’ve reviewed your imaging and feel it’s feasible.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: If I’m asleep for it, that’s better. I just don’t want to wake up without a line again.

conversation.speaker: NURSE
conversation.text: Your morning labs show your hemoglobin is down to about 10.3 and your platelets are around 103, and your white count is still low at 3.1. Your kidney numbers are higher again, with creatinine 8.6 and BUN 59, so nephrology is eager to get dialysis restarted once the new line is in.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: I feel more tired and a little puffy. I can tell when I’m due for dialysis.

conversation.speaker: CONSULT
conversation.text: We’re the interventional radiology team again. Under general anesthesia, we successfully placed a tunneled hemodialysis catheter through your left common femoral vein with the tip in your right atrium. It was very difficult to advance the catheter past the left iliac vein and through the IVC, and a small contrast injection suggested there might be partial thrombus in the IVC. However, the catheter is functioning well and is ready for dialysis.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: Because of that possible IVC thrombus seen during the catheter placement, we’re going to start you on a heparin drip while we get more definitive imaging. We’ve ordered a CT venogram of your abdomen and pelvis to see if there’s truly a clot in the IVC. If there is, we may need to continue blood thinners; if not, we’ll stop them.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Blood thinners make me nervous. I’ve heard they can cause bleeding. Do I really need that?

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: We understand your concern. That’s why we’re using heparin, which we can turn off quickly, and we’re checking your clotting labs regularly. If the CT shows there’s no clot, we’ll stop the heparin after about a day. If there is a clot, we’ll weigh the risks and benefits of longer‑term blood thinners, especially given your platelet counts and medication adherence.

conversation.speaker: NURSE
conversation.text: We’ve started your heparin infusion and your first dialysis session through the new left femoral catheter. Your potassium before dialysis was 5.8 and your BUN and creatinine were 70 and 10, so this should help bring those down. Let us know if you feel lightheaded or short of breath during dialysis.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: I feel okay so far, just the usual tired feeling. I hope this line keeps working.

conversation.speaker: CONSULT
conversation.text: I’m from radiology. We reviewed your CT of the abdomen and pelvis with contrast. The IVC is fully opacified and there is no filling defect—so no evidence of an IVC thrombus. The catheter is in place and the IVC is patent. We also see innumerable bilateral renal cysts and two small splenic lesions that look like hemangiomas, but no retroperitoneal lymphadenopathy.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: That’s great news: the CT confirms there’s no clot in your IVC, so we’re going to stop the heparin drip now. We’ll continue to use the left femoral catheter for dialysis. The CT also confirms the many kidney cysts we already knew about and benign‑appearing splenic lesions, so no signs of cancer there.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: I’m relieved there’s no clot. My leg where the new line is feels sore but not like the infected one did.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Your blood counts over the last couple of days show a stable macrocytic anemia with hemoglobin around 9–10, white blood cells in the mid‑2s to low‑3s, and platelets drifting down into the 90s. Your coagulation tests are normal. We think this pancytopenia is related to your HIV and chronic kidney disease. We’ll continue to monitor, but you haven’t needed any transfusions.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: I’m used to my blood counts being low, they always tell me that at dialysis. As long as I don’t need a transfusion, I’m okay with it.

conversation.speaker: NURSE
conversation.text: Your labs this morning show your creatinine is down to about 4.7 and BUN 27 after dialysis, and your potassium is 4.7. Calcium is a bit low at 7.9, and your phosphorus is slightly low at 2.6, so the team has already reduced your sevelamer dose and started Nephrocaps to help with vitamins.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: They told me they were cutting back the sevelamer because my phosphorus was low. I’ll take whatever pills I need if it helps me stay out of the hospital.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: We also noticed your D‑dimer is quite elevated at about 6991, but given the CT showing no IVC clot and your lack of symptoms like chest pain or shortness of breath, we’re not pursuing further clot workup right now. Your lactate is normal at 1.4, and your blood cultures from admission and the next day have shown no growth, so it looks like we caught the line infection early and treated it effectively.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: So even though that line looked nasty, the infection didn’t get into my blood? That’s good.

conversation.speaker: CONSULT
conversation.text: I’m from cardiology, reviewing your rhythm issues. During dialysis you had an EKG that showed premature atrial beats in a bigeminal pattern, but your heart rate was actually around 80 and you had no symptoms. On older EKGs you’ve had atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response during sepsis. Given your low CHADS2 score and concerns about adherence, we’re not recommending warfarin. Instead, your aspirin dose has been increased from 81 mg to 325 mg daily.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: I didn’t feel anything when they said my heart was acting funny. I can take the stronger aspirin if that helps and doesn’t mean more blood tests.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: We’re looking at your most recent labs before discharge. Your hemoglobin is about 9.5, platelets have improved to 139, and white count is 2.4. Creatinine is 5.2 and BUN 34 after dialysis, potassium 5.2, and your electrolytes are otherwise stable. Coagulation tests are normal. Clinically, your blood pressure has been in the 90s to low 100s systolic without symptoms, and the right thigh infection site is healing with no fluctuance or drainage.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: I feel more like myself now. The right leg is much less sore, and the new line on the left just feels like a bruise. I can walk with my cane like before.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: We’re planning to discharge you home with visiting nurse services. You’ve completed a 7‑day course of vancomycin dosed with dialysis for the suspected right femoral catheter infection, and you never developed a positive blood culture or fever. Your new left femoral tunneled catheter is working well for dialysis. At home, you’ll continue cinacalcet, sevelamer at the reduced dose, Nephrocaps, folic acid, Bactrim three times a week after dialysis, azithromycin once weekly, gabapentin every 48 hours, hydroxyzine as needed for itching, oxycodone as needed for neuralgia pain, docusate for constipation, and aspirin 325 mg daily.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: That’s a lot of pills, but I’ve been on most of them already. I’ll keep going to dialysis on my usual days. Will someone check on this new line and the old site on my right leg?

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Yes. The visiting nurse will check your catheter sites and your right thigh wounds, and your nephrologist will see you in dialysis. We’ll also arrange follow‑up with your HIV provider to keep discussing HAART when you feel ready, and with your primary doctor for your neuralgia and anemia. If you develop fever, chills, worsening leg pain, redness or drainage around the catheter, chest pain, or trouble breathing, you should call right away or come back to the emergency department.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Okay, I understand. Thank you all for taking care of me. I’m ready to go home.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Hi, I’m one of the emergency room doctors. I know you just came over from dialysis. Can you tell me in your own words what brought you in today?

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: My right side of my head has been killing me. It’s that same shingles area around my right eye and forehead. It’s been worse the last few days, and today at dialysis I felt dizzy and lightheaded. My vision’s been blurry too.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Okay. You’ve had shingles involving that right eye before, with nerve pain there for a long time, right?

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Yeah, years now. They told me it was shingles in the eye. I’ve had this burning, stabbing pain on the right forehead and around the eye ever since.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Have you changed any of your pain medicines recently? I see you were on gabapentin before.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: I was taking 100 milligrams of gabapentin, but the pain got worse so I bumped it up myself to 300 once a day over the last few weeks. Then I started feeling really off balance and lightheaded, and my son read the side effects and told me to stop it a day or two ago.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Got it. Any fevers, chills, neck stiffness, or sensitivity to light or sound?

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: No fevers or chills. My neck feels okay. Light and sound don’t really bother me. It’s just this constant pain and itching on my face and scalp and the dizziness.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: You’re on dialysis for kidney failure from HIV, correct? When was your last dialysis and how much fluid did they take off today?

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Yes, I don’t make urine. I go three times a week. I was there today and they took off about 1.2 liters, they said.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: You also have HIV/AIDS and haven’t been on HIV medications for a while, right?

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Yeah, I’ve been off the HIV meds. I had trouble sticking with them and they made me feel sick. I know my CD4 was really low last time.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: We’ll recheck your CD4 count today. Right now your blood pressure is on the low side, 86 over 54, and your heart rate is in the 90s. We’re going to get some blood work, a CT scan of your head, and a chest X‑ray, and start some IV fluids. We’ll also look carefully at your eye and skin.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Okay. I’m just worried it might be something in my brain or my eye again.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: That’s exactly why we’re doing the head CT and eye exam. If we’re worried about infection around the brain, we might talk about a spinal tap, but we’ll see what the first tests show.

conversation.speaker: NURSE
conversation.text: I’m going to start an IV and draw some blood now. You may feel a quick pinch. We’ll also put some dye in your eye to look for any shingles‑related damage.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Alright, just tell me before you do anything near my eye. It’s really sensitive.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: We’ve done the fluorescein exam of your right eye. We don’t see any of the classic shingles‑type scratches on the cornea. Your right eye is red, and you have those red plaques and small ulcers on the right side of your face and forehead, but nothing that looks like a new eye ulcer.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: So my eye itself looks okay?

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: So far, yes. We’ll still have the eye specialists see you once you’re upstairs, given your history of shingles in that eye.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
