conversation.text: Your first labs are back. Your white blood cell count is low at 2.4, and you have some eosinophils. Your creatinine is 5.8, which fits with your kidney failure. We also checked a blood gas that shows a normal pH and a lactate of 2.2, which is only mildly elevated.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Is that why I feel so tired all the time, the low white count?

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: The low white count is more about your immune system being weak from HIV. It doesn’t usually cause fatigue by itself, but it does mean you’re at higher risk for infections.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: We’re going to give you some IV fluids now because your blood pressure is still low. We’ll also start antibiotics—vancomycin and cefepime—to cover for possible line or other infections, and acyclovir to cover for possible shingles reactivation while we sort this out.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: I’m okay with that. I just don’t want to end up on a breathing machine or anything.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Right now you’re breathing fine on your own and your oxygen level is good. The fluids and medicines are to keep things from getting worse.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Your head CT is back. It doesn’t show any bleeding, stroke, or mass. It does show some heavy calcifications along the coverings of the brain, which we see in people with long‑standing kidney failure like you, but nothing acute.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: So there’s nothing new wrong in my brain?

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Correct—no new stroke or bleeding on the scan. If we were very worried about infection around the brain, the next step would be a spinal tap, but that’s something we’d only do if absolutely necessary.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Your chest X‑ray also looks clear—no pneumonia, no fluid in the lungs. We can see your dialysis catheter coming up from below into the right atrium, and it’s in good position.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: That’s good. My chest feels okay, just that weird feeling earlier.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: While we were giving you fluids, your heart rhythm changed briefly to atrial fibrillation—an irregular rhythm—with your heart rate around 117. You said you felt a funny feeling in your chest. It’s back to normal now, but we’re going to keep you on the monitor.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Yeah, it felt strange for a minute, but it went away. I’ve had that before when I was really sick.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: We also checked your heart enzymes. Your troponin is a bit elevated, but your CK and CK‑MB are in the normal range. Given your kidney disease, a mild bump in troponin can happen without a heart attack, but we’ll keep an eye on it.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: Given your low blood pressure, the brief atrial fibrillation, and your weak immune system, we’re going to admit you to the intensive care unit for close monitoring. We’ll continue fluids and antibiotics and watch your blood pressure and heart rhythm closely.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Do I really need the ICU? I feel a little better after the fluids.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: You’ve needed about 3 liters of fluid to get your blood pressure up from the 70s to the 90s, and with your HIV and dialysis, we’d rather be cautious. Once things are clearly stable, we can move you to the regular floor.

conversation.speaker: NURSE
conversation.text: We’re in the MICU now. Your blood pressure is around 100 over 60, heart rate in the 90s, and you’re on room air. I’m going to hook you up to the monitors and give you your usual medicines like aspirin, cinacalcet, and sevelamer, plus pain medicine if you need it.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: My head still hurts a lot. Can I get something stronger than Tylenol?

conversation.speaker: NURSE
conversation.text: You have an order for oxycodone by mouth. I’ll bring that now and we’ll see if it helps your headache and facial pain.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: Good morning. I’m the ICU attending. Overnight your blood pressure has stayed in the low 90s to 100s after the fluids, and your heart rhythm is back in normal sinus rhythm. Your labs this morning show your hemoglobin is 12.6, platelets are low at 101, and your white count is still low at 2.5. Your CD4 count is 6, which is extremely low.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Six? That sounds really bad. What does that mean for me?

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: A CD4 of 6 means your immune system is very weak and you’re at high risk for serious infections. We strongly recommend restarting HIV medications as an outpatient with your HIV doctor. In the meantime, we’re going to restart preventive antibiotics—Bactrim three times a week and azithromycin once a week—to help prevent certain infections.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: I stopped those before, but if they help keep me out of the hospital, I’ll try them again.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: We also checked your cortisol level because of your low blood pressure and eosinophils. The first level was in the low‑normal range, and we’re going to do a stimulation test with a medicine called cosyntropin to make sure your adrenal glands are working.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Is that like steroids?

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: It’s a one‑time test dose that acts like the hormone your brain uses to tell your adrenal glands to work. We measure your cortisol before and after to see if they respond properly. It’s not long‑term steroids.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: Given that your blood pressure is now close to your usual baseline and we haven’t found a clear source of infection, we’re going to stop the broad IV antibiotics and acyclovir. We’ll keep monitoring you and move you out of the ICU to the regular medicine floor later today.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: So you don’t think I have a bad infection causing this?

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: Right now, with your stable blood pressure, clear chest X‑ray, and no fever, we think your low blood pressure is more related to your usual dialysis‑related drops and possibly the gabapentin side effects, rather than a new severe infection.

conversation.speaker: NURSE
conversation.text: We’ve transferred you from the MICU to the medicine floor. Your blood pressure is in the 90s over 50s, which is your usual baseline, and your heart rhythm is normal. Let me know if your headache or itching gets worse.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: The itching on my face and body is driving me crazy. The pain is still there too.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: On exam, you have those erythematous plaques and small erosions on the right side of your face and forehead, and lots of hyperpigmented, itchy bumps on your arms, legs, chest, and abdomen. Dermatology thinks this is likely eosinophilic folliculitis related to HIV, not active shingles spreading.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: So it’s not new shingles all over?

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Correct. We don’t see new blisters like we’d expect with active shingles. It looks more like chronic inflammation of the hair follicles. We’re treating the itching with fexofenadine twice a day and Sarna lotion as needed.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: The allergy pill helps a bit, but I still scratch in my sleep.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: This morning’s labs show your hemoglobin is 11.1, white count 2.8, and platelets 119. Your creatinine is 9.8 and BUN 57 before dialysis, potassium is 5.3, and your bicarbonate is 23. These are in the range we expect before your dialysis session.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: So I still need my regular dialysis today?

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Yes. The renal team has arranged for you to get hemodialysis today on your usual schedule. We’ll continue your sevelamer and cinacalcet as well.

conversation.speaker: NURSE
conversation.text: We’re taking you down for dialysis now. Your blood pressure is in the 90s over 50s. During dialysis, your pressure may drop; if it does and you feel dizzy, tell us right away.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: It always drops a bit, but I’ll let you know if I feel bad.

conversation.speaker: NURSE
conversation.text: During dialysis your blood pressure dipped into the 60s to 70s systolic, but you didn’t feel dizzy. We gave you a 200 cc normal saline bolus and your pressure came back up.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: I didn’t really feel it that much. I’m used to my pressure being low after dialysis.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Your post‑dialysis labs tomorrow will likely show your creatinine and potassium coming down. For now, your blood pressure is back in the 80s to 90s systolic, which is your baseline, and you’re not having any symptoms.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: My head still hurts, though. The pain is like a burning line on my forehead.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: We think this is post‑herpetic neuralgia from your prior shingles. We’ve restarted amitriptyline at night, which you said helped you in the past, and you still have oxycodone and acetaminophen as needed.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: I remember that pill helping before. I’ll try it again.

conversation.speaker: CONSULT
conversation.text: I’m from Ophthalmology. We examined your right eye. There’s chronic scarring and a sluggish pupil from your prior shingles, but we don’t see any new corneal lesions or acute eye infection. Your blurry vision seems related to the old damage, not something new.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: So nothing new is attacking my eye right now?

conversation.speaker: CONSULT
conversation.text: Correct. We don’t see signs of new shingles in the eye or other acute problems. Continue the pain regimen your primary team has started.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Your cosyntropin stimulation test results are back. Your cortisol levels rose appropriately, so there’s no evidence of adrenal insufficiency. That means your adrenal glands are working fine.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: So my low blood pressure isn’t from bad adrenal glands?

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Right. It’s more likely from your usual dialysis‑related drops and your chronic low baseline, not from adrenal failure.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: We’re also continuing aspirin 325 mg daily for your atrial fibrillation risk. Given your low stroke risk score and concerns about bleeding and adherence, we’re not starting warfarin.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: I can handle the aspirin. I don’t want to be on blood thinners that need a lot of checks.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: Your labs this morning show hemoglobin 11.6, white count 2.1, platelets 113, creatinine 7.0, BUN 34, and potassium 4.9. These are stable for you after dialysis. Your blood pressure is in the 80s to 90s systolic, and you’re walking around the room without dizziness.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: I still feel tired, but I can get around. The itching is better with the pills and lotion, and the head pain is a bit less with the amitriptyline.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: Given how stable you are, we’re planning to discharge you home later today. You’ll continue your regular dialysis schedule, your HIV prophylaxis with Bactrim three times a week and azithromycin once a week, aspirin, cinacalcet, sevelamer, fexofenadine, amitriptyline at night, and your pain medicines as needed.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Will someone go over all the pills with me before I leave? It’s a lot to keep track of.

conversation.speaker: NURSE
conversation.text: Yes, we’ll review each medication and give you a written list. We’ll also make sure you have follow‑up appointments with your primary doctor, dermatologist, HIV doctor, and that your dialysis schedule continues as usual.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Okay. I just want to stay out of the hospital if I can.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: That’s our goal too. The most important things are to keep going to dialysis, take your prophylactic antibiotics, use the amitriptyline and pain meds as prescribed, and talk with your HIV doctor about restarting antiretroviral therapy. If you get new fevers, worsening headache, vision changes, or feel much more dizzy, come back right away.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Hi, I’m one of the medicine residents. I know you just came up from the emergency department. Can you tell me in your own words what brought you in tonight?

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: My right-sided headache’s been worse for a few days, and the pain over the right side of my face is really bad. I also noticed new blisters on the right lower part of my face and more itching. I got dizzy and a little short of breath after dialysis this morning, so my doctor told me to come to the ER.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: You’ve had shingles involving that right eye and scalp before, with ongoing nerve pain there, correct? Any change in your vision from your usual baseline in the right eye?

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Yes, I had shingles on the right side with my eye involved before, and the pain never really went away. My right eye has been bad since then, but it’s not worse than usual now.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: In the ER they told me your blood counts were a bit low and your kidney numbers were high, which is expected with your dialysis. Your potassium was also elevated, so they started treatment for that. We’ll continue to monitor your labs closely. Right now your blood pressure and temperature are at your usual baseline and you don’t have a fever.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Okay. I know my kidneys are bad. I just feel worried about these blisters and the pain. Are you thinking the shingles is back?

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Because of your history and the new right facial lesions, we are concerned about possible zoster reactivation, especially since your immune system is very weak from HIV. In the ER, Ophthalmology looked at your eyes and didn’t see any new dendritic lesions, and they recommended acyclovir eye ointment for a week. You also received an oral dose of acyclovir and IV morphine for pain there. We’ve started IV and oral acyclovir here as well while we wait for more tests.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: They did put some ointment in my eyes downstairs and gave me something for pain. The pain is a little better now, but the itching is driving me crazy. I usually take hydroxyzine at home for that.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: We can restart hydroxyzine for your itching and also use topical treatments. I see you have a long-standing itchy rash on your arms and legs as well, which Dermatology later thought was eosinophilic folliculitis related to your HIV. We’ll have Dermatology see you and they may do skin biopsies to clarify what’s going on with both the chronic rash and the new facial lesions.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: If they have to do biopsies, that’s fine. I just want to know what this rash is and stop the itching.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: You also mentioned your HIV medicines. You restarted HAART about two weeks ago with abacavir, atazanavir, ritonavir, and emtricitabine. We’ll continue those here, along with your prophylaxis with Bactrim three times a week and azithromycin weekly to prevent opportunistic infections.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Yes, they just restarted those pills a couple weeks ago. I try to take them like the bottles say, but it’s a lot to keep track of.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: We’ll help organize them while you’re here and make sure you leave with clear instructions. For tonight, we’ll keep you on the medicine floor, continue acyclovir, manage your pain and itching, and monitor your labs and heart rhythm, since you have a history of atrial fibrillation.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Okay. I’ve had that irregular heartbeat before, but I don’t feel anything funny in my chest right now.

conversation.speaker: NURSE
conversation.text: I’m your nurse tonight. Your vital signs are stable—your blood pressure is in the 90s over 50s, which is your usual, and your oxygen is 100% on room air. I’ll bring your pain medicine and hydroxyzine now, and we’ll keep an eye on your heart monitor.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Thank you. I’d like something for the headache too if I can have it.

conversation.speaker: NURSE
conversation.text: You’re due for oxycodone now, and the doctor also ordered acetaminophen for headaches. I’ll give you the oxycodone first and see how you do.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: That sounds good. The Percocet-type pills usually help some.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: Good morning. I’m the attending on the medicine service. I’ve reviewed your labs and imaging so far. Your CT chest doesn’t show signs of PCP pneumonia, just some small granulomas and a ground-glass spot in the right lower lobe that could be from infection or aspiration, but nothing acute. Your oxygen levels and exam are reassuring.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: So my lungs are okay? I get short of breath when I walk, but that’s been going on for years.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: Yes, nothing new in the lungs. You’ve had exertional shortness of breath for years and prior workups showed only mild pulmonary hypertension. We’ll keep monitoring, but right now there’s no evidence of PCP or fluid overload on the CT.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: Regarding your rash and facial pain, Dermatology and Infectious Disease will see you today. They may biopsy the skin on your arm and face to distinguish between zoster and other causes like eosinophilic dermatitis or drug reaction. We’ll continue IV acyclovir until we have more information.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Okay. Will those biopsies hurt a lot?

conversation.speaker: CONSULT
conversation.text: Hi, we’re from Dermatology. We see the chronic itchy papules on your arms and legs and the ulcerations on your right cheek. Given your HIV and the high eosinophil count in your blood, this could be an eosinophilic dermatitis or drug reaction rather than active shingles. We’d like to do small punch biopsies from your left arm and right face under local anesthesia.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: If it helps figure this out, go ahead. I just don’t want big scars on my face.

conversation.speaker: CONSULT
conversation.text: We’ve finished the biopsies—one from the left arm and one from the right cheek. You have a few sutures on the right side of your face now. We’ll send these to pathology. Early results will likely be back in a couple of days, and we’ll update you. For now, we agree with continuing acyclovir until we’re sure it’s not zoster.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: All right. It’s sore but tolerable. How long will the stitches need to stay in?

conversation.speaker: CONSULT
conversation.text: The facial sutures should come out in about a week, and the arm sutures in about two weeks. We’ll make sure that’s in your discharge instructions.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: This morning’s labs show your potassium is still a bit high and your kidney numbers are up, which we expect before dialysis. Nephrology has arranged your usual hemodialysis session today, and they’ve ordered kayexalate as well. We’re also continuing your cinacalcet and sevelamer, and we doubled your sevelamer dose to help with high phosphate.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: I usually get dialysis Monday, Wednesday, Friday, so that sounds right. I don’t like that kayexalate, but I’ll take it if I have to.

conversation.speaker: NURSE
conversation.text: We’re taking you down for dialysis now. Your blood pressure is a little low but similar to your usual. If you feel dizzy during dialysis, let the nurses there know right away.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: I usually get lightheaded during dialysis. Sometimes they have to give me some saline.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: You’re back from dialysis. The team reports you had some low blood pressure during the run, but it improved with a small saline bolus. Your post-dialysis labs show your potassium and BUN have come down.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Yeah, I felt woozy for a bit, but I feel okay now. The headache is still there though.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: We’re still working up the headaches. Your CT head yesterday didn’t show any bleeding, stroke, or mass. Given your HIV and the worsening headaches with some photophobia, we’re planning a lumbar puncture tomorrow under fluoroscopic guidance to look for infections like meningitis or cryptococcus.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: I’ve had headaches for a long time, but lately they’re more often and sometimes the light bothers me. If the spinal tap will help rule out infections, I’ll do it, but I’m nervous.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: That’s understandable. Radiology will use imaging to guide the needle, and they’ll collect some spinal fluid for tests. We’ll also give you something like lorazepam to help with anxiety during the procedure.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Okay. I’d like something to calm me down for that.

conversation.speaker: CONSULT
conversation.text: We’re the Neuroradiology team. We’ll be doing your lumbar puncture now. We’ll numb the area with lidocaine and use fluoroscopy to guide the needle. If you feel any sharp pain or tingling, let us know.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: All right. I’m still a bit scared, but I’m ready.

conversation.speaker: CONSULT
conversation.text: We’ve completed the lumbar puncture and collected clear spinal fluid. There were no complications. You may have some soreness in your lower back. Try to lie flat for a bit, and let the floor team know if you develop a severe positional headache.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: My back feels a little sore, but otherwise I’m okay. I hope this tells you what’s causing the headaches.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Your spinal fluid results are back. The white cell count is very low, protein and glucose are normal, and the cryptococcal antigen is negative. Cultures and viral studies so far show no growth. This makes meningitis or other CNS infections very unlikely.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: That’s a relief. So the headaches aren’t from an infection in my brain?

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Correct. Between the normal CT head, the normal MRI brain, and the reassuring spinal fluid, we don’t see evidence of infection, bleeding, or mass. It may be a chronic headache disorder or related to your neuralgia. We’ll continue to treat the pain with oxycodone and, if needed, a combination medication with acetaminophen, caffeine, and butalbital.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: I’ve tried a lot of headache medicines before without much luck, but the oxycodone does help some.

conversation.speaker: CONSULT
conversation.text: We’re back from Dermatology with your biopsy results. Both the left arm and right face biopsies show an ulcer with neutrophilic crust and a superficial lymphocytic infiltrate with eosinophils, consistent with a hypersensitivity or drug reaction with follicular accentuation. HSV and VZV stains are negative, and cultures from the tissue only grew coagulase-negative staph. Overall, this fits eosinophilic dermatitis or folliculitis rather than active zoster.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: So it’s not shingles again? That’s good. What does that mean for treatment?

conversation.speaker: CONSULT
conversation.text: Right, we don’t see evidence of active shingles. We recommend stopping acyclovir now. For the rash, we’ll continue hydroxyzine for itching and start mupirocin cream twice daily on the facial lesions. We don’t think you need systemic antibiotics like cephalexin for impetigo at this point.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Okay. I’m glad I don’t need more IV antivirals. The cream and the itch pills sound fine.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: This morning your facial ulcerations and pustules look much better, and the chronic prurigo on your legs is healing. Your pain is improved but still present. We’ll continue hydroxyzine, mupirocin, and your neuropathic pain medicine desipramine, and keep oxycodone-acetaminophen as needed.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: The rash does look less angry, and the itching is a bit better. The face still hurts, but not as bad as when I came in.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: Your blood counts remain low but stable—white cells around 2.5 to 3.5, hemoglobin around 10 to 11, and platelets just over 100. Coagulation tests are normal, and you haven’t had any bleeding. This is likely from HIV-related bone marrow suppression and chronic disease. We’ll continue to monitor but don’t need transfusions.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: I’ve been told my counts are low before. As long as I’m not bleeding, I’m okay with not getting blood.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: We repeated your basic labs today. Your creatinine is again elevated before dialysis, and your BUN and phosphate are up, but your potassium is in the mid-4s. We’ll continue your Monday–Wednesday–Friday dialysis schedule and the higher sevelamer dose. Your bicarbonate and anion gap are acceptable.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Dialysis always makes me tired, but I know I need it. I’m glad the potassium isn’t as high now.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Your MRI brain from this evening is normal—no infarct, hemorrhage, or abnormal signal. That, along with the CT and LP, really reassures us there’s no structural or infectious cause for the headaches. We’ll keep managing them symptomatically.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Good to know. The headaches are still there but at least I know it’s not something like a tumor or bleeding.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: We’re getting close to sending you home. Your vital signs are at your baseline—blood pressure in the mid-90s over 50–60s, heart rate 80–90, afebrile, and oxygen saturation 100% on room air. Your facial lesions are healing, the rash and itching are improved, and your headaches and facial pain are better controlled with your current regimen.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: I do feel better than when I came in. The itching is much less, and the face doesn’t hurt as much, though I still have some pain.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: For discharge, we’ll send you home with your HAART regimen—abacavir, atazanavir, ritonavir, and emtricitabine—as well as Bactrim three times a week and azithromycin weekly. You’ll continue cinacalcet and sevelamer for your kidneys, aspirin for your atrial fibrillation, desipramine for neuropathic pain, hydroxyzine as needed for itching, oxycodone-acetaminophen for pain, and mupirocin cream for the facial rash.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: That’s a lot of medicines, but I’ll do my best. Will someone go over the schedule with me before I leave?

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Yes, we’ll give you a written list and review it with you. We’ve also arranged follow-up with your HIV doctor and instructions for suture removal—face sutures in about one week and arm sutures in about two weeks. You’ll continue your regular outpatient dialysis schedule as well.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Okay. I’ll make sure to go to those appointments and dialysis. Thank you all for taking care of me.

conversation.speaker: NURSE
conversation.text: Your discharge paperwork is ready. You’re going home with visiting services, and transport will be here shortly. I’ve gone over your medications and when to call your doctors. Do you have any last questions before you leave?

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: No, I think I’m all set. I just want to get home and rest.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Hello, I’m one of the medicine residents. I know you just came up from the emergency department. Can you tell me in your own words what brought you in today?

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: I had dialysis earlier. I got home and was lying on the couch, and all of a sudden I felt really weak and lightheaded. The room felt like it was spinning a bit. I couldn’t even get myself off the couch. I threw up once and then called 911 because I couldn’t get to the door.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: So this started after you finished your dialysis and got home, and the main things were weakness, lightheadedness, and one episode of vomiting. Any fever, chills, chest pain, shortness of breath, cough, belly pain, or diarrhea?

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: No fevers or chills. No chest pain or trouble breathing. My stomach’s okay, no diarrhea or pain. Just that one time I threw up. Mostly I just felt so weak and dizzy.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: In the emergency room your blood pressure was quite low at first, and they gave you some IV fluids and an antibiotic called Zosyn just in case there was an infection. Your blood pressure has come up since then. Do you remember anyone mentioning that to you?

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: They said my pressure was low and they were giving me fluids and some strong medicine for infection, but they didn’t find anything specific. I usually run low after dialysis anyway.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: You’re right, you told us your blood pressure is usually in the 80s to 90s after dialysis. I also see you started a new medication, pregabalin—Lyrica—for your nerve pain two days ago, and you had balance problems with gabapentin in the past. Is that right?

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Yes, my doctor started me on Lyrica two days ago for the pain on the right side of my face and head. I didn’t like gabapentin before because it made me feel off balance. This feels kind of similar, just worse.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: That’s very helpful. We’re concerned that the Lyrica may be causing these symptoms, especially given your kidney disease. We’re going to stop that medication now. We’ll also keep an eye out for infection, but so far your chest X-ray looks clear and your blood work doesn’t show a clear source.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Okay, I don’t want to take that again if it’s making me feel like this. I just don’t want to have this pain all the time either.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: We’ll work on safer options for your nerve pain. For now, we’ll use other pain medicines and we’re planning to start a low-dose medication called duloxetine later, after talking with your outpatient doctors. We’ll also monitor your blood pressure and check your labs again in the morning.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Alright. My head still hurts on the right side like it always does from the shingles I had there. I just don’t want to feel so dizzy.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: We’ll give you something for the headache and keep checking on the dizziness. If you feel the room spinning again or feel worse, please call the nurse right away.

conversation.speaker: NURSE
conversation.text: Hi, I’m your nurse tonight. I’m going to check your vital signs and get you settled. How are you feeling right now—still lightheaded?

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: A little lightheaded when I sit up, but not as bad as before. Mostly just tired and my right head and eye area hurt like usual.

conversation.speaker: NURSE
conversation.text: Your blood pressure is still on the low side but close to what the doctors say is normal for you after dialysis. I’ll bring you some acetaminophen for the pain, and you also have a stronger pain pill ordered if you need it.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Okay, I’ll try the Tylenol first. Thank you.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: I’m the attending physician on the medicine team. I’ve reviewed your chart and the resident’s note. You came in with sudden lightheadedness and weakness after dialysis, with one episode of vomiting, and you recently started Lyrica. Is that correct?

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Yes, that’s right. It came on all of a sudden after I got home from dialysis. I started Lyrica two days ago.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: Given your history of feeling off balance on gabapentin and the timing with Lyrica, we think this is most likely a side effect of that medication, possibly worsened by your kidney disease and low blood pressure after dialysis. We’ve stopped Lyrica and will not restart it. We’re also watching for infection, but your chest X-ray is clear and your initial labs don’t show a clear infection source.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: So you think it’s the Lyrica and not an infection? They scared me a bit in the ER talking about sepsis.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: Right now, infection seems unlikely. You don’t have fever or localizing symptoms, your chest X-ray is normal, and your blood cultures so far show no growth. We started broad antibiotics at first because your blood pressure was low and you’re immunocompromised, but we’ve stopped them now that you’re stable and there’s no evidence of infection.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Okay, that makes me feel better. I just want this dizzy feeling to go away so I can go home.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: Our plan is to observe you, keep you hydrated, manage your pain, and make sure the lightheadedness improves off Lyrica. If you continue to feel better and your labs look okay, we’ll be able to send you home with some medication changes and follow-up.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Will I still get my dialysis like usual while I’m here?

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: Yes. You’re on a Monday, Wednesday, Friday schedule, and we’ll make sure you get hemodialysis here on your usual day. The nephrology team will see you and arrange it.

conversation.speaker: NURSE
conversation.text: Good morning. I’m checking on you before your labs. How are the dizziness and weakness today compared to when you came in?

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: I still feel a little weak, but the spinning feeling is mostly gone. I can sit up without feeling like I’m going to pass out.

conversation.speaker: NURSE
conversation.text: That’s good to hear. We’ll draw your morning blood work now to check your counts and kidney numbers, and the doctors will be by on rounds soon.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: We have your morning labs. Your blood counts show mild anemia and low platelets, similar to your baseline, and your white count is a bit low but stable. Your kidney numbers are higher than normal because you haven’t had dialysis yet—your creatinine is 8.1 and your potassium is 6.5, so we’re arranging dialysis for today.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: I figured my kidneys would be off since I missed my regular place. Is that potassium dangerous?

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: A potassium of 6.5 is higher than we like, but we caught it early and you’re going to dialysis shortly, which will bring it down. We’re also monitoring your heart rhythm. Right now your EKG and vital signs are stable.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Okay. I don’t feel anything different in my heart, just the usual tiredness.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: That’s reassuring. The dialysis nurses will give you your usual medications during dialysis, including your vitamin D and some heparin for the machine. If you feel chest pain, palpitations, or worse dizziness during dialysis, tell them right away.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: I will. I’ve had dialysis for a long time, so I know what to look out for.

conversation.speaker: NURSE
conversation.text: They’re ready for you in dialysis. We’ll take you down now. You’ll get some of your medicines there, including something to help with itching and your bone health.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Okay. My skin has been so itchy, so anything that helps is good.

conversation.speaker: CONSULT
conversation.text: Hi, I’m from the nephrology team. We’re overseeing your dialysis today. We see you have ESRD from HIV-related kidney disease and dialyze three times a week. Today we’ll run your usual treatment and watch your blood pressure closely, since you came in with low pressures.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Thanks. I usually feel wiped out after dialysis, but yesterday was worse than usual.

conversation.speaker: CONSULT
conversation.text: Understood. We’ll be conservative with how much fluid we remove today to avoid dropping your pressure too much. You’ll also get your usual medications through dialysis, like doxercalciferol and heparin, and we’ll recheck your labs afterward.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Alright. I’ll let you know if I feel funny.

conversation.speaker: NURSE
conversation.text: You’re back from dialysis. How are you feeling now?

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Tired, like usual after dialysis, but not as dizzy as before. Just my regular headache and some itching.

conversation.speaker: NURSE
conversation.text: Your blood pressure is stable for you. I can bring you some hydroxyzine for the itching and acetaminophen or oxycodone for the headache if you’d like.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Hydroxyzine and a Tylenol would be good. I’ll save the stronger pill for later if I need it.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: This morning, how are your lightheadedness and weakness compared to when you came in?

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Much better. I still feel a little weak, but I can stand up with help and I don’t feel like I’m going to fall over. The spinning is gone.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: That’s great. Your labs after dialysis show your potassium and kidney numbers are improving, and your blood pressure has been stable. We’re confident that stopping Lyrica helped. We’re planning to start duloxetine three times a week after dialysis for your nerve pain, at a low dose, and we’ll send you home on that.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Will that duloxetine make me dizzy like the Lyrica?

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: It can have side effects, but we’re using a low dose and only after dialysis to be safer with your kidneys. We’ll ask you to watch for any new dizziness or nausea and let your outpatient doctors know. We think it’s a better option than Lyrica or gabapentin for you.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Okay, I’ll try it. I really need something for this nerve pain.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: We’re also keeping you on your prophylaxis medicines—azithromycin once a week and Bactrim three times a week—to protect you from infections related to your HIV. You’re not on your full HIV medications right now, but your outpatient infectious disease doctor is planning to restart them with blister packs after discharge.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Yeah, they gave me blister packs but I haven’t started them yet. It’s a lot of pills and I get confused.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: We understand. The team has gone through your medication list carefully because you weren’t sure of all the doses. We’ll send you home with a simplified list and recommend that you meet with a pharmacist as an outpatient to go over everything in detail.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: That would help. Sometimes I just don’t know what I’m supposed to be taking.

conversation.speaker: CONSULT
conversation.text: I’m from psychiatry. The team mentioned you’ve been feeling down. Can you tell me about your mood lately?

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: I’ve been pretty depressed. With all these health problems, it’s hard. But I’m not thinking about hurting myself.

conversation.speaker: CONSULT
conversation.text: Thank you for sharing that. It’s important that you don’t have thoughts of harming yourself. We’ll recommend that you follow up with an outpatient psychiatrist after discharge to help manage your mood along with your medical issues.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Okay. I’d be willing to talk to someone.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: We’re getting close to sending you home. Your lightheadedness and weakness have improved, your blood pressure is back to your usual range, and your labs are stable for you. We’ve stopped Lyrica, started duloxetine for your nerve pain, and adjusted your kidney medications slightly.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: So I can go home today?

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Yes, the plan is to discharge you home with visiting services. Your discharge diagnoses are lightheadedness likely from a medication side effect, along with your chronic conditions like AIDS and end-stage kidney disease. We’ll give you written instructions and a medication list.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Can you go over which medicines I’m supposed to take when I get home?

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Of course. We want you to continue aspirin once a day, azithromycin once a week, Bactrim three times a week, sevelamer with meals three times a day, cinacalcet at a lower dose once a day, hydroxyzine as needed for itching, docusate twice a day for constipation, duloxetine three times a week after dialysis for nerve pain, and acetaminophen as needed for pain. We’ve stopped Lyrica.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: That’s a lot, but it helps to hear it. And I should not take Lyrica again, right?

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Correct—do not take Lyrica again. If anyone tries to prescribe it, tell them you had dizziness and weakness from it. We’ll also put that in your chart.

conversation.speaker: NURSE
conversation.text: I have your discharge papers here. They explain that your symptoms were most likely from a side effect of Lyrica, and they list all your medications and follow-up appointments. Do you have any questions before you go?

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: No, I think I understand. I’ll follow up with my HIV doctor and dialysis center, and I’ll watch for dizziness. Thank you all for taking care of me.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Hello, I’m one of the medicine residents. I understand you came in from dialysis because of pain and swelling in your left groin where your catheter is. Can you tell me when that pain started and how it’s changed over the last few days?

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: It started about three days ago. At first it was just sore, but then it got worse and I felt a hard bump near the catheter. Today after dialysis they said it looked hot and was draining pus. I’ve also felt chills, like I might have a fever, but when they checked it at home it wasn’t high.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Thank you. Any nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, cough, shortness of breath, chest pain, or pain when you pee?

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: No, I haven’t thrown up. No diarrhea when I came in, no cough or breathing problems, no chest pain, and I don’t make urine anymore because of my kidneys.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: You have HIV and are on dialysis, correct? Are you taking any HIV medicines right now, or just the Bactrim and azithromycin to prevent infections?

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Yeah, I’ve got AIDS. They told me my CD4 was really low. I’ve been taking Bactrim and that big azithromycin pill once a week, but I haven’t been on the HIV meds for a while before this.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: On exam I see a very tender, warm, firm area just above the left femoral catheter, but I don’t see pus right now. Your vital signs are stable and your lungs and heart sound okay. Your initial labs show a low hemoglobin around 8, white count about 4, and your creatinine is elevated as expected with your kidney disease. Potassium is a bit low at 3.1, and phosphate is low at 1.5. We’re concerned about an infection of that catheter that could be in your bloodstream.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: So that line is really infected? Is that why it hurts so much?

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Yes, that’s our concern. The dialysis unit already gave you doses of ceftazidime and vancomycin before you came here, and we’ve drawn blood cultures. We’re going to get an ultrasound of the leg veins to look for a clot and talk with interventional radiology and nephrology about removing that catheter after dialysis today and sending the tip for culture.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: If you take that line out, how am I going to get dialysis?

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: We’ll coordinate with the kidney doctors. The plan is to remove the infected left femoral catheter after you get dialysis today, then give you a few days without a line to clear the infection, and then place a new tunneled catheter, likely on the right side. During that time we’ll manage your fluids and labs closely.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Okay, I’m scared but I understand. This pain is really bad though.

conversation.speaker: NURSE
conversation.text: I’m going to give you some IV Dilaudid for the groin pain as ordered, and we’ll keep checking your blood pressure and breathing. If the pain doesn’t improve, let me know.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Thank you, it really hurts when I move my leg.

conversation.speaker: CONSULT
conversation.text: Hi, I’m from interventional radiology. We’ve reviewed your ultrasound, which didn’t show a clear clot in the left femoral or superficial femoral veins, though the study was limited because of your pain. We’re going to remove the tunneled hemodialysis catheter in your left groin now and send the tip for culture.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Will that make the infection go away?

conversation.speaker: CONSULT
conversation.text: Removing the infected catheter plus the IV antibiotics you’re getting gives you the best chance to clear the infection from your blood. We’ll do this under local anesthesia; you’ll feel some pressure but we’ll try to keep you comfortable.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Alright, just please don’t let it hurt too much.

conversation.speaker: CONSULT
conversation.text: We’ve removed the left femoral tunneled dialysis catheter without complications. The tip has been sent for culture. A dressing is in place over the site. Let us know if you notice bleeding or increased swelling.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: It’s sore, but I’m glad it’s out. What happens next?

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Your blood cultures and the catheter tip culture are pending. We’ve started you on IV vancomycin, and you already received gentamicin and ceftazidime earlier. We’ll be checking your vancomycin levels and kidney labs closely, especially since you’re on dialysis.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Okay. I just feel tired and don’t feel like eating much.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: This morning your labs show your hemoglobin is still around 8, white count about 3.6, and your creatinine is 5.8 with BUN 21. Electrolytes look acceptable. Your vancomycin level is high at 33.6, so pharmacy will help us adjust the dosing around dialysis.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Is that bad, that the antibiotic level is high?

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: It just means we need to be careful with the dose so you don’t get side effects. Because you don’t make urine, the drug stays in your body longer, and dialysis helps clear it. We’ll time the doses after dialysis and keep checking levels.

conversation.speaker: NURSE
conversation.text: You’re going down for dialysis now. Since your old line was removed, they’ll be using temporary access as arranged by nephrology. We’ll continue your vancomycin after dialysis per the protocol.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Alright. I’m nervous without my usual line, but I know I need dialysis.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: Your cultures are back. The catheter tip and wound culture from your left groin grew methicillin-resistant Staph aureus, MRSA. One of your blood cultures also grew the same organism, confirming bacteremia. The good news is your follow-up blood cultures have shown no growth so far.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: So the infection was in my blood too? Is that why I’ve been feeling so wiped out?

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: Yes, that’s right. A bloodstream infection can make you feel very fatigued. We’ll continue IV vancomycin for a total of three weeks, given after your dialysis sessions, to fully treat the MRSA bacteremia and catheter infection.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Three weeks is a long time, but I’ll do what I have to.

conversation.speaker: CONSULT
conversation.text: I’m from nephrology. Your phosphorus has been running low, around 1.5 to 1.6, so we’re going to hold your sevelamer for now. We’ll continue cinacalcet and your renal vitamins. We’ll also plan for a new tunneled dialysis catheter on the right side after a three-day line holiday.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Okay, so I stop that big phosphate pill for now? And the new line will be on the other side?

conversation.speaker: CONSULT
conversation.text: Yes, we’re holding the phosphate binder. And tomorrow we’ll place a tunneled catheter in your right common femoral vein under imaging guidance so you can continue dialysis more comfortably.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: I just hope this one doesn’t get infected too.

conversation.speaker: CONSULT
conversation.text: We’ve just placed a right common femoral tunneled hemodialysis catheter. The tip is in the right atrium and the line is ready for use. There were no immediate complications.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: My right groin feels sore, but not as bad as the other side did.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: We’re going to get a transesophageal echocardiogram because of the MRSA in your blood, to look for any infection on the heart valves or on the new catheter tip.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: That’s the test where they put a tube down my throat, right? Will I be asleep?

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: Yes, it’s the one with a small ultrasound probe in the esophagus. You’ll get sedation so you’re drowsy and comfortable, and we’ll monitor you closely.

conversation.speaker: CONSULT
conversation.text: I’m from cardiology. Your first TEE showed a small atrial septal defect and that the dialysis catheter was actually crossing from the right atrium into the left atrium through that defect, with a small mobile mass on the catheter tip that likely represented thrombus. We started you on a heparin drip to anticoagulate you.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: So the line went into the wrong side of my heart? Could that cause a stroke?

conversation.speaker: CONSULT
conversation.text: It was passing through a small hole between the upper chambers, and that’s why we were worried about clot and stroke risk. After 48 hours of heparin, a repeat TEE showed that the mass on the catheter tip had resolved. We then exchanged the catheter for a shorter one so the tip now sits in the upper inferior vena cava, away from the defect.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: I’m glad that clot is gone. Do I have to stay on blood thinners forever now?

conversation.speaker: CONSULT
conversation.text: Cardiology recommended long-term anticoagulation, especially since you have atrial fibrillation and kidney disease, but given concerns about medication adherence and your preference, we are not starting warfarin now. We’ll continue aspirin only.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Honestly, I don’t think I could keep up with all the blood tests for warfarin, so I’m okay with that.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: You’ve started having frequent watery bowel movements since yesterday, and your stool test came back positive for C. difficile, a bacterial infection of the colon often triggered by antibiotics. We’re stopping the oral vancomycin we briefly used and have started you on oral metronidazole three times a day for 14 days.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: That explains the diarrhea. Will this new antibiotic fix it?

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Yes, metronidazole is effective for mild to moderate C. diff. Keep taking it even if the diarrhea improves, and we’ll make sure you have enough pills to finish the 14-day course at home.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: We also spoke with your HIV doctor. Given your very low CD4 count and high viral load, and after discussing goals of care with you, we’re restarting antiretroviral therapy: abacavir, atazanavir boosted with ritonavir, and emtricitabine. You’ll continue Bactrim and azithromycin for prophylaxis.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: That’s a lot of pills. I got confused before. How am I supposed to take them with dialysis?

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: We’ll give you written instructions. For example, take emtricitabine after dialysis on Mondays and Fridays, and take the others once daily, ideally after dialysis as well. Your outpatient HIV doctor and pharmacist will review this with you again.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Okay, if it’s written down and someone goes over it with me, I think I can manage.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Your labs this morning show your hemoglobin is 7.7, hematocrit 24, white count 3.4, and platelets 244. Creatinine is 5.7, BUN 35, sodium 138, potassium 4.0, bicarbonate 27, and phosphate 3.4. These are stable for you, though you remain anemic and leukopenic.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: I still feel tired, but not as bad as when I came in. The diarrhea is slowing down too.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: On exam today, your temperature is normal, blood pressure is about 98 over 65, heart rate 75, and you’re breathing comfortably on room air. Your right groin catheter site looks clean without redness or tenderness, and the left groin removal site is healing under the dressing. Your heart murmur we heard earlier has resolved, and your lungs are clear.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: So does that mean I can go home soon?

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: Yes. You’re stable for discharge today. You’ll go home with visiting nurse services. You’ll continue dialysis on your usual schedule, and at each dialysis session you’ll receive IV vancomycin for a total of three weeks from when we started, to complete treatment for the MRSA bacteremia. You’ll also keep taking Flagyl for C. diff until the 14-day course is done, and continue your HIV medicines and prophylaxis.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Will someone at dialysis know about the antibiotics and my new HIV meds?

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Yes, we’re sending detailed discharge paperwork to your dialysis center and your HIV clinic. The dialysis unit will have orders to give vancomycin after each session until the end date, and your follow-up appointments are arranged. If you get fever, chills, or drainage from the new catheter site, or if the diarrhea worsens, you should seek urgent care.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Alright. Thank you all for taking care of me and explaining everything.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Hi, I’m one of the medicine residents in the emergency department. I’ve read that you came in because your right leg has been swelling. Can you tell me when you first noticed the swelling and how it’s changed over the last few days?

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: It started a few days ago and just kept getting bigger. It’s my whole right leg, from the thigh down. It feels heavy and hurts when I walk. I just had this new dialysis line put in on the right side not long ago, so I was worried it might be related.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Thanks, that helps. Any redness, warmth, or drainage around the catheter site in your right groin? Any fevers, chills, shortness of breath, or chest pain?

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: No, the skin around the line looks okay to me—no pus or anything. I haven’t had fevers or chills. I do feel some mild pressure in my chest sometimes and I’ve had a dry cough, but I’ve had that for a bit. Breathing is okay.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Got it. I see from your chart that you have HIV with a low CD4 count, are on hemodialysis for kidney failure, and you recently had a left femoral dialysis catheter removed for a MRSA infection and a right femoral catheter placed. You also have a history of atrial fibrillation and post‑herpetic neuralgia around your right eye. Is that all still correct?

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Yes, that’s right. They took out the left line because it got infected with MRSA. Now I’ve got the right one. I’m on dialysis three times a week. My HIV doctor just restarted my meds recently. My heart goes into A‑fib sometimes, but they told me it’s been okay lately. And my right eye and forehead still hurt from the shingles I had there.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: In the ER your vital signs have been stable, but your labs show your potassium is a bit high and your creatinine is up, which we expect with your kidney failure. Your blood counts are low but similar to your baseline. We’re also concerned about a possible clot in the veins of your right leg or around the catheter, so we’re going to get an ultrasound of the leg veins and some more blood work. We’ll also give you pain medicine while we sort this out.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Okay. I just don’t want another infection like last time. And this leg really hurts. I’ll do the tests you need.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: I’m the attending physician here. Your initial labs show a potassium of about 5.5 and creatinine around 7.3, which fits with needing dialysis soon. Your hemoglobin is in the 8 range and hematocrit mid‑20s, similar to your usual anemia. We’ll coordinate with nephrology to get you dialyzed on your regular schedule and watch your potassium closely.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: As long as I can still get my dialysis, that’s fine. I usually go three times a week. I’m just scared this swelling means something is wrong with the new line.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: That’s understandable. The ultrasound we ordered will look for clots in the leg veins and around the catheter. If we see a clot, we’ll talk about blood thinners. If we don’t, we’ll still consider whether there could be a clot higher up that the ultrasound can’t see and may need more imaging.

conversation.speaker: NURSE
conversation.text: I’m your nurse. I’m going to give you some morphine now for the leg pain, and we’ll get you ready to go down for the ultrasound. If you feel more short of breath or the pain suddenly worsens, please hit the call button right away.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Thank you. The pain is pretty bad, so I’m glad for something to take the edge off.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Your right leg ultrasound is back. It shows no deep vein thrombosis in the right leg veins, and they can see your hemodialysis catheter entering the right common femoral vein without any clot around the visible part of the line.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: So there’s no clot in the leg? Then why is it so swollen?

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: The ultrasound can’t see the entire course of the catheter higher up in the pelvis. Because of your symptoms and your history of a catheter‑related clot across the atrial septal defect on your last admission, we’re going to get a CT scan of your pelvis with contrast to look at the larger veins around the catheter.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: I remember they told me last time the line went through a hole in my heart and had a clot on it. They put me on heparin for a couple of days. I really don’t want that to happen again.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: Your CT pelvis shows a lot of right leg edema. The tunneled dialysis catheter takes up most of the right external iliac vein, which makes it hard to see if there’s a clot right around the line, but the other pelvic veins look open. Given your swelling and the limited view, we’re going to treat this as a likely clot around the catheter and start you on a heparin drip, then transition you to warfarin.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: So you’re sure there’s a clot even though they couldn’t see it clearly? And this time you want me on warfarin long‑term? I was scared of that before.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: We can’t see the clot directly because the catheter fills most of that vein on CT, but with your symptoms and risk factors, the safest course is to treat it as a clot. On your last admission, cardiology recommended long‑term anticoagulation because of your atrial fibrillation and the catheter‑related clot, but it wasn’t started due to concerns about adherence and your preference. Given this new presumed clot, we strongly recommend warfarin now, and we’ll arrange close INR monitoring through your dialysis unit.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: If it will keep me from getting more clots or a stroke, I’ll try it. I just need help keeping track of all these meds and blood tests.

conversation.speaker: NURSE
conversation.text: We’ve started your heparin drip through your IV. We’ll be drawing your PTT blood test regularly to make sure the dose is in the right range. If you notice any bleeding from your gums, nose, or in your stool, or if you get a bad headache, please tell us right away.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Okay, I’ll let you know. I bruise easily already, so I’m a little nervous about more blood thinners.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: This morning’s labs show your hemoglobin is about 8.9 and hematocrit 28.3, similar to your baseline anemia. Your white count is around 4, and your platelets are normal. Your potassium is 5.7, creatinine 7.9, and BUN 59, so nephrology will dialyze you today. Your CD4 count is 39 with a CD4 percentage of 4% and a low CD4/CD8 ratio, consistent with advanced AIDS, so we’ll continue your antiretroviral regimen and prophylactic antibiotics.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: So my blood counts are about the same as usual? And I keep taking the HIV meds and the Bactrim and azithromycin like at home?

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Yes, your counts are similar to your baseline. We’re continuing abacavir, atazanavir with ritonavir, and emtricitabine, as well as Bactrim three times a week and azithromycin weekly. We’ll also keep your aspirin, cinacalcet at a reduced dose, sevelamer, nephrocaps, duloxetine, and your pain and itch medicines.

conversation.speaker: CONSULT
conversation.text: Hi, I’m from the nephrology team. We’ll continue your hemodialysis on your usual schedule while you’re here. Today we’ll dialyze you and give you epoetin for anemia, ferric gluconate for iron, and doxercalciferol for your secondary hyperparathyroidism, along with heparin during dialysis and a heparin dwell for the catheter.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Okay. I usually feel better after dialysis. Will that help the swelling in my leg too?

conversation.speaker: CONSULT
conversation.text: Dialysis will remove extra fluid, which often helps with swelling. In your case, the leg edema is also likely related to the catheter and possible clot, but we’ve already seen that your swelling improves after dialysis sessions, and we expect that to continue.

conversation.speaker: NURSE
conversation.text: Your morning labs show your potassium is down to 4.8 and your creatinine is about 4.9 after dialysis. Your hemoglobin is 9.0 and hematocrit 27.5. The doctors are happy with these numbers. We’ll keep checking your PTT and INR while you’re on heparin and starting warfarin.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Good to hear. My leg does feel a bit less tight today. But now my right eye is puffy and stuck shut in the morning with some gunk. It worries me because of the shingles I had there before.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: I see the swelling and some discharge around your right eye. Given your history of herpes ophthalmicus in that area, we’re going to have ophthalmology see you. In the meantime, we’ll start an antibiotic eye ointment and valacyclovir by mouth to cover both bacterial conjunctivitis and possible viral reactivation.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: I really don’t want that shingles in my eye again. It was awful. I’ll use whatever drops or pills you give me.

conversation.speaker: CONSULT
conversation.text: I’m from ophthalmology. Your right eye has some periorbital swelling and purulent discharge, consistent with conjunctivitis. Because of your prior herpes in this area, we agree with starting polymyxin/bacitracin ophthalmic ointment and a 7‑day course of valacyclovir. We’ve also sent tests from a forehead lesion for HSV and VZV; so far, the direct antigen tests and cultures have not shown herpes or varicella‑zoster.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: So it’s more like an eye infection than shingles coming back? That’s a relief. I’ll keep using the ointment and pills.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Your coagulation labs overnight show your PTT is in the 60–70 second range on the heparin drip, which is therapeutic, and your INR is still around 1.0. We’ll keep the heparin going while we increase your warfarin dose to get your INR into the 2–3 range.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: I’ve heard people say their blood gets ‘too thin’ on these meds. Are my numbers okay, or is there a risk of bleeding?

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: Right now your PTT is high because of the heparin, which is what we want while we’re bridging you. Your INR is just starting to rise with warfarin and is not yet in the target range. We’re watching closely and adjusting doses daily. We’ll stop the heparin once your INR has been in the therapeutic range twice in a row, and we’ll continue to monitor for any signs of bleeding.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Alright. I’ll keep an eye out for any bleeding and tell you if I notice anything.

conversation.speaker: NURSE
conversation.text: Your labs this morning show your hemoglobin is about 8.9, hematocrit 28.1, white count 3.7, and platelets 182. Your creatinine is 6.6 and BUN 43, potassium 4.6, and your INR is 1.7 with a PTT of about 86. We’ve adjusted your heparin and the doctors increased your warfarin dose yesterday.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: My leg looks almost back to normal now. The swelling is way down. Does that mean the clot is getting better?

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Yes, the fact that your right leg edema has largely resolved, especially after dialysis, is a good sign that the circulation is improving. We’re going to continue the heparin until your INR is solidly in the therapeutic range, then stop the drip and keep you on warfarin alone.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: That’s good news. My eye also feels a lot better—just a little puffiness left.

conversation.speaker: CONSULT
conversation.text: We’re checking back from ophthalmology. Your periorbital swelling has almost completely resolved, and there’s minimal discharge now. You should finish the 7‑day course of valacyclovir and continue the polymyxin/bacitracin ointment until that course is done. You don’t need a separate ophthalmology follow‑up; your primary doctor can monitor it.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Okay, I’ll keep using the ointment and pills until they’re finished.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Your labs today show hemoglobin 9.3, hematocrit 28.9, white count 3.3, platelets 181. Creatinine is 4.1, BUN 20, potassium 3.9, and your INR is 1.6 with a PTT around 96. We’re getting closer to the INR goal, and your kidney numbers look good post‑dialysis.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: So I still need both the drip and the pills for now?

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: Yes, for now. Once your INR is in the 2–3 range and stable, we’ll stop the heparin drip and you’ll continue warfarin alone. We’re also planning your discharge home with services, and your dialysis unit will draw your INRs and fax them to your providers so we can keep your warfarin dose safe and effective.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: I’m okay with going home as long as someone helps me keep track of the blood tests and the warfarin dose.

conversation.speaker: NURSE
conversation.text: Your INR early this morning is 2.2 and your PTT is about 90.6. That means your warfarin is now in the therapeutic range. The team will be stopping your heparin drip soon and keeping you on warfarin alone.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: So after they stop the drip, I’ll just be on the warfarin pills? Do I need to change anything I eat?

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Yes, we’ll stop the heparin drip now that your INR is therapeutic and keep you on warfarin. With warfarin, it’s important to keep your vitamin K intake consistent—so avoid big sudden changes in foods like leafy greens. We’ll give you written instructions and your dialysis unit will check your INR regularly.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: I don’t eat a lot of salads anyway, but I’ll try to keep things the same. Just tell me what dose to take.

conversation.speaker: RESIDENT
conversation.text: Your labs this morning show hemoglobin 9.2, hematocrit 28.6, white count 3.9, platelets 187. Creatinine is 5.1, BUN 24, potassium 4.5, and your INR is 3.0 with a PTT of about 142. We’ll adjust your warfarin dose slightly to keep the INR in the 2–3 range, but you’re safe for discharge today.

conversation.speaker: ATTENDING
conversation.text: We’re planning to discharge you home with visiting nurse services today. Your right leg swelling has resolved, your eye infection has nearly cleared, and your dialysis catheter is functioning well. You’ll continue your home hemodialysis schedule, your HIV medications and prophylaxis, your pain and itch medicines, and now warfarin 6 mg daily. Your dialysis unit will draw your INR and fax the results to your providers as ordered.

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: Thank you. I’m glad the leg and my eye are better. I’ll go to dialysis like usual and make sure they do the blood tests. I just want to stay out of the hospital if I can.

conversation.speaker: NURSE
conversation.text: Here are your discharge instructions and medication list. It includes your HIV meds, dialysis‑related meds, eye ointment and valacyclovir to finish the 7‑day course, your pain medicines, and warfarin 6 mg daily. It also explains when your dialysis unit should draw your INR and where to fax the results. Do you have any questions before we arrange your ride home?

conversation.speaker: PATIENT
conversation.text: No, I think I understand. I’ll follow up with my primary doctor and the clinic like it says. Thanks to all of you for taking care of me.
